revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1631|music}}
The year '''1631 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
== Events == *[[January 9]] – The [[masque]] ''[[Love's Triumph Through Callipolis]]'', written by [[Ben Jonson]] and designed by [[Inigo Jones]], is performed at [[Whitehall Palace]]; the work features music by [[Nicholas Lanier]]. * In [[Venice]], the [[Italian plague of 1629–31|plague outbreak of 1629–1631]], after reducing the population by one third, comes to an end. [[Claudio Monteverdi]] writes a mass for a service of thanksgiving, held at [[St Mark's Basilica]]. *[[Marco Marazzoli]] is one of several musicians who accompany Cardinal [[Antonio Barberini]] on a visit to [[Urbino]]. *Earliest known bentside [[spinet]], made by Hieronymus de Zentis.<ref>[[Frank Hubbard]] (1967)</ref>
== Publications == * [[Thomas Morley]] – an edition of his [[Canzonetta|canzonets]]. *[[Cornelis Padbrué]] – ''Kusjes'' (collection of madrigals)
== Classical music ==
{{Empty section|date=July 2017}}
== Opera == *[[Stefano Landi]] – ''[[Sant'Alessio]]'' (with libretto by [[Giulio Rospigliosi]]): Palazzo Barberini alle Quattro Fontane, 18 February 1632.<ref>Margaret Murata, "Land, Stefano", ''New Grove Dictionary of Opera'', new edition, edited by Stanley Sadie (London: Macmillan Publishers, 1998).</ref>
== Births == *October – [[Pierre Beauchamp]], choreographer, dancer and composer (died 1705) *[[October 3]] – [[Sebastian Anton Scherer]], composer (died 1712)
== Deaths == *[[January 3]] – [[Michelagnolo Galilei]], lutenist and composer (born 1575) *[[March 24]] – [[Philipp Dulichius]], composer (born 1562) *[[August 6]] – [[Juan Blas de Castro]], singer and composer (born 1561) *''date unknown'' – [[Christoph Straus]], German choral composer (born 1575)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1631|Music]] [[Category:1631 in music| ]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{Year nav topic5|1690|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1690'''.
==Events== *[[December 10]] – Playwright [[Henry Nevil Payne]] is tortured for his role in the [[Montgomery Plot]] to restore [[James II of England|James II]] to the throne — the last time a political prisoner is subjected to torture in Britain. *[[Colley Cibber]] becomes an actor with the [[Drury Lane]] company.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Nicholas Barbon]] – ''A Discourse of Trade'' *[[Pierre Bayle]] (attributed) – ''Avis important aux refugies'' *Sir [[Thomas Browne]] (posthumously) – ''[[A Letter to a Friend]]'' *[[Antoine Furetière]] (posthumously) – ''Dictionnaire universel'' *[[John Locke]] **''[[An Essay Concerning Human Understanding]]'' (dated this year but published 1689) **''[[Two Treatises of Government]] *[[Samuel Pepys]] – ''Memoires of the Navy'' *[[Baro Urbigerus]] – ''Aphorismi Urbigerani''
===Drama=== *John Bancroft – ''King Edward III, with the Fall of Mortimer, Earl of March'' *[[Aphra Behn]] (posthumously) – ''The Widow Ranter'' *[[Thomas Betterton]] – ''[[Dioclesian|The Prophetess, or The History of Dioclesian]]'' (adapted from [[John Fletcher (playwright)|Fletcher]] and [[Philip Massinger|Massinger]]'s ''[[The Prophetess]]'', with music by [[Henry Purcell]]) *[[Edmé Boursault]] – ''Esope à la ville'' *[[Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery]] – ''Mr. Anthony'' *[[John Crowne]] – ''The English Friar, or the Town Sparks'' *[[John Dryden]] **''[[Amphitryon (Dryden)|Amphitryon, or the Two Sosias]]'' **''Don Sebastian'' *[[George Powell (playwright)|George Powell]] **''Alphonso, King of Naples'' **''The Treacherous Brothers'' *[[Elkanah Settle]] – ''Distress'd Innocence, or The Princess of Persia'' *[[Thomas Shadwell]] – ''The Scourers'' *[[Thomas Southerne]] – ''Sir Anthony Love'' *"W. C." – ''The Rape Reveng'd, or the Spanish Revolution'' (adapted from [[William Rowley (dramatist)|William Rowley]]'s ''[[All's Lost by Lust]]'')
===Poetry=== *[[Thomas D'Urfey]]: **''Collin's Walk Through London and Westminster''<ref name=cocel>Cox, Michael, editor, ''The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature'', Oxford University Press, 2004, {{ISBN|0-19-860634-6}}</ref> **''New Poems'' *''See also [[1690 in poetry]]'' *[[Antonio Hurtado de Mendoza]] – ''Obras líricas y cómicas, divinas y humanas''
==Births== *[[February 3]] – [[Richard Rawlinson]], English antiquary and cleric (died [[1755 in literature|1755]]) *[[September 12]] – [[Peter Dens]], Netherlandish theologian (died [[1775 in literature|1775]]) *1689/90 – [[Susanna Highmore]], English poet (died [[1750 in literature|1750]])
==Deaths== *[[March 21]] – [[Henry Teonge]], English diarist and cleric (born [[1621 in literature|1621]]) *[[May 5]] – [[Theodore Haak]], German-born English translator and natural philosopher (born [[1605 in literature|1605]]) *[[May 12]] – [[John Rushworth]], English author of ''Historical Collections'' (born c. 1612) *[[October 3]] – [[Robert Barclay]], Scottish Quaker writer (born c. 1648) *[[October 25]] – [[Cornelius Hazart]], Dutch Jesuit controversialist (born [[1617 in literature|1617]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Franciscus Plante]], Dutch poet (born [[1613 in literature|1613]]) *''Probable year of death'' – [[Jeremias Felbinger]], German writer, teacher and lexicographer (born [[1616 in literature|1616]])
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} [[File:Arts District, Las Vegas, United States (Unsplash).jpg|thumb|right|250px|A Pink Cadillac in the Downtown Arts District.]]
The '''Las Vegas Arts District''', or the '''18b''' in [[Downtown Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] was created in 1998 as an 18 block zone set aside to encourage art and artists.<ref>{{cite web | title=Downtown Arts District | url=http://www.fodors.com/world/north-america/usa/nevada/las-vegas/review-178016.html | work=[[Fodor's Travel]] | publisher=[[Random House]] | accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
The district won [[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'s ''Best of Las Vegas'' award in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|first= Ken |last = White| title=Downtown Arts District finally taking hold | url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/bestoflv/2005/bestartsdistrict.jsp;jsessionid=BMGLLJLEFKAA | work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] | accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
Known as the 18b, the Las Vegas Arts District contains a mix of independent businesses including [[vintage clothing]] boutiques, antique stores, art galleries, hair salons, restaurants, The 18b is located halfway between the Fremont East Entertainment district and the Stratosphere Resort, clustered around Main and Charleston, bounded loosely by Commerce Street to the West, Hoover Avenue to the North, Fourth Street to the East and Wyoming Avenue at the south. It is an easy bike ride, walk or bus ride from Fremont Street. The name, "18b," represents the original Arts District area, which consisted of 18 blocks. Today, the Arts District area has grown beyond those original 18 blocks and is a classic urban mix of residential, commercial and cultural uses that will continue to grow as the hub of the arts scene in Las Vegas.
The "First Friday" Art Walk is a monthly arts and cultural event drawing up to 30,000 visitors into the neighborhood on the first Friday evening of each month. This event encourages people to flock downtown to browse, buy, eat, drink and mingle. The event is a festival environment with food and beverage vendors, music, visual performances and artists/artisans/craftspeople displaying their works.
== Events == The district hosts a ''First Friday'' art walk on the first Friday of every month. First Friday offers an eclectic group of artists as well as "entertainers of all types, including local bands, fire breathers, acrobats, break dancers, fortune tellers and performance artists."<ref>{{cite web | title=Artsy Schmartzy | url=http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/page.aspx?id=148648 | publisher=[[United Jewish Communities]] | accessdate=9 May 2009}}</ref>
In addition to ''First Friday'', Preview Thursday is held preceding night before the block party. It is a subdued night of gallery openings and special events around the arts district without the large crowds that the main event can bring.
== Boundaries == The district is loosely bounded by Hoover Avenue, Wyoming Avenue, [[Las Vegas Boulevard]], and Commerce Street. The official bounds are visible on the ''City of Las Vegas'' website.
== Select businesses within the district == {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[1StopDJShop]] – DJ Equipment of all kinds. Open by appointment. *[[Alios Entertainment and Architectural Lighting]] – Sometimes open as a popup gallery space on Main Street. *[[ArtCulture PR]] – a boutique firm bridging the gap between arts and commerce for artists, creatives and cultural organizations; specializing in branding, social media, public relations and project management. *[[Artifice Bar]] – Bar and live performance venue. *[[The Arts Factory]] – A building with numerous art galleries and studios. *[[Art Square]] – Fully renovated warehouse building housing a variety of creative industry businesses. *[[Atomic Style Lounge]] – Full service salon for women and men, featuring era specific looks. *Bastille – Formerly Snick's. Oldest continually operating gay bar in Nevada, and the only one downtown. *[[Brett Wesley Gallery]] – High end international contemporary art gallery. *[[Blackbird Studios]] – Artist collective studio and gallery space. *[[Brian Garth#Chrome Werewolf|Chrome Werewolf]] recording studio. *[[Buffalo Exchange]] – Used clothing boutique. *[[Casa Don Juan]] – Mexican food. *[[City of the World]] – Indie Music Venue, skill sharing space and art gallery. *[[Cockroach Theatre]] – Theatre troupe resident at Art Square Theatre *[[Cornerstone Gallery]] – Street art culture gallery and venue on Colorado ave. *[[D E Thai]] – Original Single dish Thai street food made with fresh ingredient. *[[Dray Studio & Gallery]] – Inside the Arts Factory. *[[El Sombrero]] – Mexican Food. *[[Glam Factory Vintage]] – Vintage clothing boutique on Colorado ave. *[[Globe Salon]] – High end hair salon at Soho Lofts. *[[The Goodwich]] – Gourmet sandwiches in Soho Lofts. *[[Haven Craft]] – Pagan and witchcraft community center and store. *[[HellPop]] – Comic Book store inside the Arts Factory. *[[Hop Nuts]] – Microbrewery and hand crafted beers. *[[Hot Mess Boutique]] – Urban hipster boutique on 3rd Street. *[[Inside Style]] – Interior design and showroom. *[[Rock'n'oodles]] Noodle dishes from around the world, inspired by rock music. *Jammyland Cocktail Bar and Reggae Lounge – Craft cocktail and rum bar. *[[JJ Clocks & Antiques]] – Quality antiques and clocks plus repairs and restorations. *[[Josephine Skaught Salon]] – Salon with independent hairdressers. *[[Koolsville Tattoo]] – Las Vegas' oldest tattoo shop. *[[Las Vegas Ballet School]] – Teaching all ages and levels. *[[Las Vegas Contemporary Arts Center]] – Non-profit Arts Organization gallery in Soho Lofts. *[[Las Vegas Oddities and Antiquities]] – Antiques, restorations, home decor, estate-jewelry and more. *[[Luxe Rust]] – Home Decor, Event Planning, Interior Design and customized gifts on Main Street. *[[Makers and Finders]] – Vibrant coffee bar and Latin comfort food. *Main Source – Street art supplies and community wall liaison. *[[Main Street Mercantile]] – Antiques, collectibles, reproductions and bespoke wear. *[[Majestic Repertory Theater]] – Repertory Theatre on Main. *[[Modern Mantiques]] – Antiques and collectibles, Restoration, Movie/Prop rentals, men's vintage clothing, and much more. *[[Martin's Mart]] – Thrift and Retro Clothing. *[[Mingo's]] – Bar and restaurant serving a variety of fusion dishes. *[[List of condominiums in Las Vegas#Newport Lofts|Newport Lofts]] – Luxury lofts of all sizes with ground floor retail suites. *[[Neuveda Dispensary]] – MMJ Dispensary on Third street. *[[oogoog productions]] – Creative video production. *[[Patina Decor]] – Upscale vintage furniture and retro apparel. *[[Photo Bang Bang]] – Studio rentals, workshops and more. *[[ReBAR]] – Beer. Booze. Bargains. Antiques and drinks on Main Street. *[[Retro Vegas]] – Mid-century boutique on Main street. *[[Rode'o Raggz]]- Rock and Roll Clothing *[[Sandman Studios]] – Artistic glassworks and etching. *[[Sin City Gallery]] – contemporary art for the modern provocateur, specializing in local and international artists, featuring an array of mediums and styles, and producer of [[12 Inches of Sin]] art show. *[[Sin City Yoga]] – Traditional yoga school offering a variety of membership based and drop in classes for all levels on Main Street. *[[List of condominiums in Las Vegas#Soho Lofts|Soho Lofts]] – Loft style condos of all sizes with ground floor retail suites. *Unhinged – Unique craft boutique *Velveteen Rabbit – Hip urban lounge and venue on Main Street. *[[Vesta Coffee]] – Fresh roasted, specialty grade coffee and restaurant on Casino Center. *[[Vintage Vegas]] Vintage and Mid-century collectables *[[We Talk Chalk]] – 3D Street Painting Studio & Gallery – Chalk Art – Street Art – Anamorphic Paintings.
{{div col end}}

{{Year nav topic5|1940|film|television|radio }} The year '''1940 in film''' involved some significant events, including the premieres of the [[Walt Disney]] films ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'' and ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]''.
==Events== *February 7 - [[Walt Disney]]'s animated film ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'' is released, which is considered the greatest animated film of all time. * February 10 - [[Tom and Jerry]] make their debut in the animated [[cartoon]] ''[[Puss Gets the Boot]]''. * March 21 - [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s first American film ''[[Rebecca (1940 film)|Rebecca]]'' is released, under the production of [[David O. Selznick]]. It would go on to win the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]] the following year. * May 17 - ''[[My Favorite Wife]]'' is released. * May - A reproduction of "America's First Movie Studio", [[Thomas Edison]]'s [[Edison's Black Maria|Black Maria]], is constructed. * July 27 - [[Bugs Bunny]] makes his official debut in the animated cartoon ''[[A Wild Hare]]''. * October 15 - Charlie Chaplin's ''[[The Great Dictator]]'', a satirical comedy starring him, is released. * November 13 - World premiere of Walt Disney's ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]'' at the [[Broadway Theatre (53rd Street)|Broadway Theatre]] in New York City, the first film to be released in a multi-channel sound format (''see [[Fantasound]]''). The film also marks the first use of the [[click track]] while recording the soundtrack, overdubbing of orchestral parts, simultaneous multitrack recording and is cited as a key chapter in the conception and development of the multi-channel surround system. * December 5 - Release of ''[[The Thief of Bagdad (1940 film)|The Thief of Bagdad]]'', pioneering the use of [[chroma key]] effects. * In the United Kingdom, the [[Crown Film Unit]] supersedes the [[GPO Film Unit]] in the production of [[documentary film]]s.
==Top-grossing films (U.S.)<ref>Box Office Digest, April 1941, p. 18</ref>== At the time, box office numbers were reported as a percentage of business for each theater in comparison to 'normal' business. For example, [[Boom Town (film)|Boom Town]] performed at 232% and [[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]] at 130%. This is why exact dollar grosses for films are unreliable at best. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Rank || Title || Studio || Gross |- | 1. |''[[Rebecca (1940 film)|Rebecca]]'' | United Artists | '''$6,000,000''' |- | 2. | ''[[Boom Town (film)|Boom Town]]'' | MGM | '''$5,000,000''' |- | 3. | ''[[The Great Dictator]]'' | United Artists | '''$5,000,000''' |- | 4. | ''[[Strike Up the Band (film)|Strike Up the Band]]'' | MGM | '''$3,494,000''' |- | 5. |''[[The Philadelphia Story (film)|The Philadelphia Story]]'' | MGM | '''$3,259,000''' |- | 6. | ''[[Northwest Passage (1940 film)|Northwest Passage]]'' | MGM | '''$3,150,000''' |- | 7. | ''[[Andy Hardy Meets Debutante]]'' | MGM | '''$2,623,000''' |- |- | 8. | ''[[New Moon (1940 film)|New Moon]]'' | MGM | '''$2,527,000''' |- | 9. | ''[[The Grapes of Wrath (film)|The Grapes of Wrath]]'' | 20th Century-Fox | '''$2,500,000''' |- | 10. | ''[[Kitty Foyle (film)|Kitty Foyle]]'' | RKO | '''$2,385,000''' |- | 11. | ''[[Comrade X]]'' | MGM | '''$2,079,000''' |- | 12. | ''[[My Favorite Wife]]'' | RKO | '''$2,057,000''' |- | 13. | ''[[The Sea Hawk (1940 film)|The Sea Hawk]]'' | Warner Bros. | '''$2,000,000''' |- | 14. | ''[[Down Argentine Way]]'' | 20th Century-Fox | '''$2,000,000''' |- | 15. | ''[[Road to Singapore]]'' | Paramount | '''$1,600,000''' |} <nowiki>*</nowiki> After theatrical reissues

Selznick]], [[United Artists]] *[[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]]: '''[[John Ford]]''' - ''[[The Grapes of Wrath (film)|The Grapes of Wrath]]'' *[[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]: '''[[James Stewart]]''' - ''[[The Philadelphia Story (film)|The Philadelphia Story]]'' *[[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]: '''[[Ginger Rogers]]''' - ''[[Kitty Foyle (film)|Kitty Foyle]]'' *[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]: '''[[Walter Brennan]]''' - ''[[The Westerner (film)|The Westerner]]'' *[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]: '''[[Jane Darwell]]''' - ''[[The Grapes of Wrath (film)|The Grapes of Wrath]]''

revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|2016|art}}
The year '''2016 in [[art]]''' involves various significant events.
==Events== *March - The [[Met Breuer]] opens in the former home of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/03/04/arts/music/vijay-iyer-and-mark-turner-help-open-the-met-breuer.html?_r=0&referer=https://www.google.com/|title=Vijay Iyer and Mark Turner Help Open the Met Breuer|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:Whitney Museum of American Art.JPG|thumb|right|267px|The Whitney Museum of American Art's former (1966–2014) home on Madison Avenue; the [[Marcel Breuer]]-designed building was leased by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] beginning in 2016. It is now known as the Met Breuer.]] *[[July 28]] - The re-discovery of [[Albrecht Dürer]]'s engraving ''[[Mary with Infant Jesus]]'' previously considered lost since World War II is reported.<ref name="blou">{{cite web | url =http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1468921/flea-market-find-alsatian-collector-returns-long-lost-durer|title=Flea Market Find: Alsatian Collector Returns Long Lost Dürer Engraving to Stuttgart Staatsgalerie|publisher=[[Louise Blouin Media]]| date=July 28, 2016| accessdate =August 8, 2016}}</ref> The engraving was noticed in good condition at a flea market in [[Sarrebourg]] and returned to [[Staatsgalerie Stuttgart]].<ref name="blou"/> *[[September 30]] - The recovery of two paintings by [[Vincent van Gogh]], ''[[Seascape at Scheveningen]]'' and ''[[Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church in Nuenen]]'', stolen in 2002, is announced.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/en/news-and-press/press-releases/two-stolen-van-gogh-paintings-recovered-after-14-years|title=Two stolen Van Gogh paintings recovered after 14 years|publisher=Van Gogh Museum| date=30 September 2016| accessdate =30 September 2016}}</ref> *[[December 19]] - The [[List of ambassadors of Russia to Turkey|Russian Ambassador to Turkey]]; [[Andrei Karlov]] is shot dead at [[point-blank-range]] in an act of [[Assassination of Andrei Karlov|political assassination]] (by Mevlüt Mert Altıntaş who is believed to have been an off duty Turkish police officer) while giving a speech at an exhibition of Russian photographs at the [[Çankaya, Ankara (district)|Çankaya]] Contemporary Arts Center in [[Ankara]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/russian-ambassador-to-turkey-wounded-in-ankara-shooting-attack/ar-AAlKgzn?OCID=ansmsnnews11# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-12-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221121247/http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/russian-ambassador-to-turkey-wounded-in-ankara-shooting-attack/ar-AAlKgzn?OCID=ansmsnnews11# |archive-date=2016-12-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/world/europe/russia-ambassador-shot-ankara-turkey.html|title=Russian Ambassador to Turkey Is Assassinated in Ankara|publisher=}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== *[[January 20]] until [[April 17]] - "In the Lion's Den: Daniel MacDonald, [[Ireland]] and Empire" at [[Ireland’s Great Hunger Museum]] at [[Quinnipiac University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/02/19/arts/design/the-artist-who-dared-to-paint-irelands-great-famine.html?referer=http://ighm.org/|title=The Artist Who Dared to Paint Ireland’s Great Famine|publisher=}}</ref> *[[February 5]] until [[April 27]] - [[Peter Fischli]] [[David Weiss (artist)|David Weiss]]: How to Work Better" at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/exhibition/peter-fischli-david-weiss-how-to-work-better|title=Peter Fischli David Weiss: How to Work Better|date=2 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[February 18]] until [[May 15]] - "[[Georgia OKeefe|O'Keefe]], [[Florine Stettheimer|Stettheimer]], [[Helen Torr|Torr]], [[Marguerite Zorach|Zorach]]: Women Modernists in New York" at the [[Norton Museum of Art]] in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norton.org/exhibitions|title=Norton Museum of Art - Current Exhibition|website=www.norton.org}}</ref> *[[February 18]] until [[June 13]] - "[[Edvard Munch|Munch]] and Expressionism" at the [[Neue Galerie]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neuegalerie.org/content/munch-and-expressionism-0|title=Neue Galerie New York|first=Neue Galerie New|last=York|publisher=}}</ref> *[[March 18]] until [[September 4]] - "Unfinished: Thoughts Left Visible" at the [[Met Breuer]] in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/unfinished# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-04-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407234307/http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/unfinished# |archive-date=2016-04-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[March 2]] until [[June 5]] - "[[Van Dyck]]: The Anatomy of Portraiture" at the [[Frick collection]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frick.org/exhibitions/van_dyck#sthash.Kun5OgD8.dpuf|title=Past Exhibition - The Frick Collection|website=www.frick.org}}</ref> *[[March 23]] until [[July 10]] - "[[Umberto Boccioni]]: Genio and Memoria (Genius and Memory)" at the [[Palazzo Reale]] in [[Milan, Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milanmuseumguide.com/umberto-boccioni-genio-memoria/|title=Umberto Boccioni exhibition at Palazzo Reale Milan|date=5 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[March 26]] until February 1, 2017 - "[[Alex Da Corte]]: Free Roses" at [[Mass MOCA]] in [[North Adams, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artsy.net/show/mass-moca-alex-da-corte-free-roses|title=Alex Da Corte: Free Roses - MASS MoCA - Artsy|website=www.artsy.net}}</ref> *[[April 27]] until [[June 19]] - "Andra Ursuta: Alps" at the [[New Museum]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/andra-ursuta-alps|title=Andra Ursuta: Alps|website=www.newmuseum.org}}</ref> *[[May 7]] until [[November 27]] - "A [[Third Gender]]: Beautiful Youths in Japanese Prints" (curated by Asato Ikeda) at the [[Royal Ontario Museum]] in [[Toronto, Ontario]], Canada then traveled to the [[Japan Society (Manhattan)|Japan Society]] in New York City from March 10 until June 11, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/exhibitions/a-third-gender-beautiful-youths-in-japanese|title=A Third Gender: Beautiful Youths in Japanese Prints|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japansociety.org/page/programs/gallery/a-third-gender |title=A Third Gender: Gallery: Programs |publisher=Japan Society |date= |accessdate=2018-09-20}}</ref> *[[May 27]] until [[September 7]] - "[[Moholy-Nagy]]: Future Present" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in [[New York City]].<ref>at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York City.</ref> *[[June 10]] until [[September 25]] - "[[Stuart Davis (painter)|Stuart Davis]]: In Full Swing" at the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/StuartDavis|title=Stuart Davis: In Full Swing|website=whitney.org}}</ref> *[[June 18]] until April 16, 2017 - "[[Tony Oursler]]: Imponderable" at [[MOMA]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.moma.org/2016/04/tony-oursler-imponderable/|title=Tony Oursler: Imponderable|website=press.moma.org}}</ref> *[[September 1]] until [[October 23]] - ''[[Bjork]] [[Björk Digital|Digital]]'' at [[Somerset House]] in [[London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.somersethouse.org.uk/visual-arts/bjork-digital|title=Björk Digital|date=7 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[September 2]] until January 8, 2017 - "[[Hans Memling]]: Portraiture, Piety, and a Reunited Altarpiece at the [[Morgan Library]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themorgan.org/exhibitions/hans-memling|title=Hans Memling: Portraiture, Piety, and a Reunited Altarpiece|date=5 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[September 16]] until January 2, 2017 - "[[Carmen Herrera]]: Lines of Sight" at the Whitney Museum of American Art.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/CarmenHerrera|title=Carmen Herrera: Lines of Sight|website=whitney.org}}</ref> *[[September 30]] until January 29, 2017 - "Los Angeles to New York: [[Virginia Dwan|Dwan Gallery]], 1959-1971" at the [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington D.C.]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/18/arts/design/virginia-dwan-a-jet-age-medici-gets-her-due.htmlaction=click&contentCollection=Art%20%26%20Design&module=RelatedCoverage&region=EndOfArticle&pgtype=article]{{Dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/exhibitions/2016/from-los-angeles-to-new-york-dwan-gallery.html|title=Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery, 1959–1971|website=www.nga.gov}}</ref> *[[October 7]] until January 16, 2017 - "[[Valentin de Boulogne]]: Beyond [[Caravaggio]]" at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/valentin-de-boulogne |title=Valentin de Boulogne: Beyond Caravaggio | The Metropolitan Museum of Art |publisher=Metmuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2018-09-20}}</ref> *October 7 until January 11, "[[Agnes Martin]]" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City.<ref>https://www.guggenheim.org/exhibition/agnes-martin></ref> *[[October 19]] until February 20, 2017 - "[[Max Beckmann]] in New York" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/max-beckmann# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-11-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104024928/http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/max-beckmann# |archive-date=2016-11-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[October 25]] - January 29, 2017 - "[[Kerry James Marshall]] : Mastry" at the Met Breuer in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/kerry-james-marshall# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-12-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221010532/http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/kerry-james-marshall# |archive-date=2016-12-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[October 26]] - January 15, 2017 - "[[Pipilotti Rist]]: Pixel Forest" at the New Museum in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/pipilotti-rist-pixel-forest|title=Pipilotti Rist: Pixel Forest|website=www.newmuseum.org}}</ref> *[[November 21]] until March 16, 2017 - "[[Francis Picabia]]: Our Heads Are Round so Our Thoughts Can Change Direction" at MOMA in New York City.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/18/arts/design/francis-picabia-the-playboy-prankster-of-moderism.html?_r=0|title=Francis Picabia, the Playboy Prankster of Modernism|publisher=}}</ref>
==Works== *[[Alice Aycock]] - "Whirpools" at [[MGM National Harbor|MGM]] [[National Harbor]], [[Oxon Hill]], [[Maryland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multivu.com/players/English/77609242-mgm-national-harbor-heritage-collection/|title=MGM National Harbor to Feature Permanent Art Collection Inspired by Capital Region’s Rich Heritage|first=MultiVu - PR|last=Newswire|website=Multivu}}</ref> *[[Kevin Beasley]] - *Who's Afraid to Listen to Red, Black and Green?" [[Morningside Park (New York City)|Morningside Park]], New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.studiomuseum.org/exhibition/inharlem-kevin-beasley-morningside-par|title=The Studio Museum in Harlem|website=www.studiomuseum.org}}</ref> *[[Christo and Jeanne-Claude]] - [[File:Correggio_-_Allegory_of_Vices_-_WGA05339.jpg|thumb|350px]] The '''''Allegory of Vice''''' is an oil on canvas painting by [[Correggio]] dating to around 1531 and measuring 149 by 88 cm.<ref>{{it icon}} Giuseppe Adani, ''Correggio pittore universale'', Silvana Editoriale, Correggio 2007. {{ISBN|9788836609772}}</ref> It and ''[[Allegory of Virtue (Correggio)|Allegory of Virtue]]'' were painted as a pair for the [[Cabinet (room)|studiolo]] of [[Isabella d'Este]], with ''Vice'' probably the second of the two to be completed. This hypothesis is since only one (possibly non-autograph) sketch survives for ''Vice'', unlike ''Virtue'', for which several preparatory studies survive, along with a near-complete under-drawing - this suggests Correggio had become more proficient after the difficult gestation of ''Virtue''.<ref>{{it icon}} Mauro Lucco (ed), ''Mantegna a Mantova 1460-1506'', exhibition catalogue, Skira Milano, 2006</ref>
Influenced by the [[Laocoön and His Sons|Laocoon]] (as is Corregio's treatment of [[Saint Roch]] in his [[San Sebastiano Madonna]] and ''Four Saints''), the central male figure is sometimes identified as a personification of Vice but sometimes as [[Silenus]] (possibly from Virgil's ''[[Eclogues]]'' 6, where a sleeping Silenus is tied up by the shepherds Chromi and Marsillo and forced to sing by them and the nymph Egle) or [[Vulcan (mythology)|Vulcan]]. It was even misidentified as [[Apollo (mythology)|Apollo]] and [[Marsyas]] by the writer of the [[Gonzaga collection]] inventory of 1542. This misunderstanding may have contributed to an ''Apollo and Marsyas'' (actually by the studio or circle of [[Bronzino]]) being historically misattributed to Correggio.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.correggioarthome.it/Sezione.jsp?idSezione=171&idSezioneRif=54|title=Giulio Sanuto, Apollo e Marsia, 1562 - Correggio ART HOME|last=srl|first=Netribe|website=www.correggioarthome.it|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref> The putto in the foreground is influenced by [[Raphael]]'s putti in the [[Sistine Chapel]].
In 1542, after Isabella's death, they were both recorded as hanging on either side of the entrance door "in the Corte Vecchia near the grotto", with ''Vice'' on the left and ''Virtue'' on the right. After the contents of her studiolo were dispersed, it remained in Mantua at least until 1627, but the following year it was sold to [[Charles I of Great Britain]]. After his execution it was purchased by [[cardinal Mazarin]] in 1661 and later by the banker [[Everhard Jabach]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cartelfr.louvre.fr/cartelfr/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=14293&langue=fr|title=Site officiel du musée du Louvre|website=cartelfr.louvre.fr|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref> who later sold it to [[Louis XIV]] in Paris, reuniting it with ''Virtue''. They both now hang in the [[Louvre]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.correggioarthome.it/Sezione.jsp?idSezione=171&idSezioneRif=54|title=Giulio Sanuto, Apollo e Marsia, 1562 - Correggio ART HOME|last=srl|first=Netribe|website=www.correggioarthome.it|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=October 2013}} {{notability|Companies|date=March 2014}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
{{Infobox Museum |name = Art Plural Gallery |image = |caption = |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = |longitude = |established = May 2011 |dissolved = |location = 38 Armenian Street, [[Singapore]] |type = [[art gallery]] |visitors = |director = Frédéric de Senarclens |website = http://www.artpluralgallery.com }}
'''Art Plural Gallery''' is an art gallery in [[Singapore]]. It shows [[modern art|modern]] and [[contemporary art]] and [[design]]. It has been called one of the ten best contemporary art galleries in Singapore<ref name=ellen>Ellen Von Wiegand. ([n.d.]) [http://theculturetrip.com/asia/singapore/articles/art-in-the-lion-city-the-ten-best-contemporary-art-galleries-in-singapore/ Art in the Lion City: The Ten Best Contemporary Art Galleries in Singapore] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818115724/http://theculturetrip.com/asia/singapore/articles/art-in-the-lion-city-the-ten-best-contemporary-art-galleries-in-singapore/ |date=18 August 2013 }}. Theculturetrip.com. Accessed October 2013.</ref> and in 2013 was named as one of the world's best new galleries.<ref name=artinfo>[http://www.artinfo.com/travel/slideshow/culture-stop-worlds-best-new-galleries-and-museums/?image=9 Culture Stop: World's Best New Galleries and Museums]. ArtInfo, 8 July 2013. Accessed October 2013.</ref>
==History==
The gallery was founded in 2011 by a Swiss art dealer, Frédéric de Senarclens. It occupies {{convert|12000|sqft|disp=flip}} in a historic [[Art Deco]] building on Armenian Street, in the cultural district of [[Singapore]].<ref name="WSJ 2011">Jane A. Peterson (9 June 2011). [https://blogs.wsj.com/scene/2011/06/09/singapore-adds-to-its-art-scene/ Singapore Adds to Its Art Scene]. The Wall Street Journal: Scene Asia. Accessed October 2013.</ref><ref name="FT 2013">Jane A. Peterson (4 October 2013). [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/4cd0649e-269d-11e3-9dc0-00144feab7de.html#axzz2kX1jXAEW Swiss art dealer on taking a gamble and moving to Singapore]. ''Financial Times'' (London). Accessed 13 November 2013.</ref><ref name=ellen/> It opened on 3 June 2011 with "Avant Première", which included works by [[Marc Quinn]], [[Fernando Botero]], [[Fabienne Verdier]], [[Bernar Venet]] and [[Shirin Neshat]].<ref name="WSJ 2011" />
Artists who have exhibited at the gallery include [[Pablo Reinoso (designer)|Pablo Reinoso]],<ref>Jessica Miller (4 January 2012). [http://www.centurion-magazine.com/nc/sections/post/between-art-and-design.html Between Art and Design: Pablo Reinoso's Inaugural South Asian Exhibition in Singapore]. Centurion Magazine. Accessed October 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.frenchmay.com/visual-arts/eventdetail/97/-/pablo-reinoso-living-sculptures Pablo Reinoso: Living Sculptures in Macau] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015040904/http://www.frenchmay.com/visual-arts/eventdetail/97/-/pablo-reinoso-living-sculptures |date=15 October 2013 }}. Le French May. Accessed October 2013.</ref> [[Ian Davenport]],<ref>Geraldine Lee (28 May 2012). [http://www.artitute.com/2012/05/28/line-and-colour-the-language-of-ian-davenport/ Line and Colour: The Language of Ian Davenport]. Artitute.com. Accessed October 2013.{{Unreliable source?|date=October 2013}}</ref> Bernar Venet,<ref>Sonia Kolesnikov-Jessop (28 September 2012). [https://web.archive.org/web/20120930001930/http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/829306/24-questions-with-bernar-venet 24 Questions For French Conceptual Artist Bernar Venet]. ArtInfo. Archived 30 September 2013.</ref> Shirin Neshat,<ref>[http://sbr.com.sg/leisure-entertainment/life-style/games-desire-be-exhibited-art-plural-gallery Games of Desire to be exhibited at Art Plural Gallery]. Singapore Business Review. Accessed October 2013.</ref> Fabienne Verdier,<ref>Kristiano Ang (8 February 2013). [https://blogs.wsj.com/scene/2013/02/06/chinese-technique-applied-to-a-western-canvas/ Chinese Technique, Applied to a Western Canvas] The Wall Street Journal: Scene Asia. Accessed October 2013.</ref><ref>Helmi Yusof (8 February 2013). [http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/archive/wednesday/lifestyle/arts/french-womans-chinese-oeuvre-20130208 French Woman's Chinese Oeuvre]. ''The Business Times'' [Singapore]. Accessed October 2013.</ref> Chun Kwang Young<ref>Sonia Kolesnikov-Jessop (5 June 2013). [http://sea.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/910735/chun-kwang-young-on-changing-direction-ever-so-slowly Chun Kwang Young on Changing Direction Ever So Slowly]. ArtInfo. Accessed October 2013.</ref> and [[Qiu Jie]].<ref>Deepika Shetty (17 September 2013). [http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/case-you-missed-it/story/cat-and-mao-game-art-20130920 A Cat and Mao Game for Art]. ''Straits Times''. Accessed October 2013.</ref>
In early 2012 the gallery started its Emerging Artists programme to promote the work of promising artists at an early stage of their career. The programme offers the selected artist a first solo show in the gallery. Siddhartha Tawadey was the first artist to exhibit under this programme.<ref name=radar>[s.n.] (12 September 2012). [http://artradarjournal.com/2012/09/12/indian-photographer-siddhartha-tawadey-inaugurates-art-plural-gallerys-emerging-artist-programme/ Indian Photographer Siddhartha Tawadey Inaugurates Art Plural Gallery’s Emerging Artist Programme]. Art Radar Asia. Accessed October 2013.</ref>
By 2013 about 35% of the clients of the gallery were from Singapore; some overseas clients visit the gallery. About 25% of sales are made online.<ref name="FT 2013" />
==Publications==
Catalogues published by the gallery include:<ref name=worldcat>[http://www.worldcat.org/search?qt=worldcat_org_all&q=%22Art+Plural+Gallery%22 "Art Plural Gallery"]. OCLC WorldCat. Accessed January 2015.</ref>
* Olivia Ludlow (2011). ''Regards Croisés: A Selection of Asian Contemporary Art''. * {{long dash}}, Henri-François Debailleux (2012). ''Pablo Reinoso: Scribbling Power''. * Joséphine Matamoros (2012). ''Tom Carr: Visualisation de la pensée''. Barcelona: Comanegra; Singapore: Art Plural Gallery. * Michael Stanley (2012). ''Ian Davenport: Between the Lines''. * Caroline Ward (2013). ''Chun Kwang Young''. * Michael Peppiatt, Jane A Peterson (2014). ''Art Plural: Voices of Contemporary Art''. Singapore: Gatehouse.

{{chinese |pic=Image:Bì (bi4) 璧 disc.jpg |piccap=A [[Han Dynasty|Han-era]] ''bi'', 16 cm in diameter. |c={{linktext|璧}} |p=bì |w=pi }} [[Image:FFB-BiScheibe.JPG|thumb|Bi disc from the Liangzhu culture ([[Museum Angewandte Kunst]], 2006)]] [[Image:Jade Bi Ornament, Dragon designs, China - Warring States period, Western Han dynasty, 4th-2nd century BC.tiff|thumb|A Western Han dynasty Bi, with dragon designs.]] The '''bi''' is a type of circular ancient [[Chinese jade]] artifact. The earliest ''bi'' were produced in the [[Neolithic]] period, particularly by the [[Liangzhu culture]] ([[3400 BC|3400]]–[[2250 BCE]]).<ref name="nga.gov">[http://www.nga.gov/education/chinatp_sl03.shtm Teaching Chinese Archaeology, object 3 - NGA<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080508040340/http://www.nga.gov/education/chinatp_sl03.shtm |date=May 8, 2008 }}</ref> Later examples date mainly from the [[Shang Dynasty|Shang]], [[Zhou Dynasty|Zhou]] and [[Han Dynasty|Han]] dynasties. They were also made in [[Ancient Chinese glass|glass]].
==Description== A ''bi'' is a flat jade disc with a circular hole in the centre. Neolithic ''bi'' are undecorated, while those of later periods of China, like the Zhou dynasty, bear increasingly ornate surface carving (particularly in a hexagonal pattern) whose motifs represented deities associated with the sky (four directions) as well as standing for qualities and powers the wearer wanted to invoke or embody.
As laboriously crafted objects, they testify to the concentration of power and resources in the hands of a small elite.<ref name="nga.gov"/>
==Meaning== Later traditions associate the ''bi'' with heaven, and the ''[[Cong (jade)|cong]]'' with the earth. Bi disks are consistently found with heaven and earth-like imagery, suggesting that the disk's circular shape also bears symbolic significance as this description explains:
{{quote|It is found that these objects testify to early stages of development of cosmological concepts that remained important in Chinese culture during the Warring States and Han periods: the notion of a covering sky (''gaitian'') that revolves around a central axis, the cycle of the Ten Suns, and the use of an early form of the carpenter's square. These objects were handled by shamans who were the religious leaders of Liangzhu society and the transmitters of cosmological knowledge.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Shu-P'Ing |first1=Teng |title=The Original Significance of ''Bi'' Disks: Insights Based on Liangzhu Jade ''Bi'' with Incised Symbolic Motifs |journal=Journal of East Asian Archaeology |date=2000 |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=165–194 |doi=10.1163/156852300509835}}</ref>}}
==Function== [[File:Bi with two dragons and grain pattern.jpg|thumb|Bi disc with a dual dragon motif, [[Warring States period]]]] The original function and significance of the ''bi'' are unknown, as the Neolithic cultures have left no written history. From these earliest times they were buried with the dead, as a sky symbol, accompanying the dead into the after world or "sky", with the cong which connected the body with the earth.<ref name="nga.gov"/> They were placed ceremonially on the body in the grave of persons of high social status. ''Bi'' are sometimes found near the stomach and chest in neolithic burials.<ref name="nga.gov"/>
Jade, like bi disks, has been used throughout Chinese history to indicate an individual of moral quality, and has also served as an important symbol of rank. They were used in worship and ceremony – as ceremonial items they symbolised the ranks of emperor, king, duke, marquis, viscount, and baron with four different ''[[Gui_(vessel)|Gui]]s'' and two different bi disks.
In war during the Zhou dynasty period (c. 1046–256 BCE), bi disks belonging to the leaders of the defeated forces were handed over to the victor as a sign of submission.
==Influences== The design of the reverse side of the medals given in the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in [[Beijing]], [[People's Republic of China|China]] are based on bi disks.<ref>[http://en.beijing2008.cn/spirit/beijing2008/graphic/n214070893.shtml Design of the Medal for the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080812163040/http://en.beijing2008.cn/spirit/beijing2008/graphic/n214070893.shtml |date=August 12, 2008 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Ancient Chinese glass#Bi disks|Glass bi disks]] *[[Cong (jade)]] *[[Huang (jade)]] *[[He Shi Bi]]

== External links == {{Commons category|Jade discs|Bi}}{{Wiktionary|bi}} *{{cite web |title=A History of the World - Object: Ancient Jade Bi, around 3,000 years-old, inscribed with a poem by its later owner, the Chinese Qianlong Emperor |date=22 September 2008 |accessdate=17 June 2010 |publisher=BBC and British Museum |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/f7two-a7R-6OhPFDbJOmIA}} * [http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/news/history-archaeology-news/jade-mystery-vin/ Video—National Geographic, Smithsonian's Freer and Sackler Galleries, Washington, D.C.; September 7, 2013]

Link is dead but the archive version is fine. Avoid using [[Template:Webarchive]] within references just as warning at the top of the documentation on that page recommends and readers given a better formatted citation that more clearly points to the archive and not the dead link.
revision.text:
{{external links|date=March 2016}} The '''Council of Science Editors''' ('''CSE''') is a [[United States]]-based nonprofit organization that supports editorial practice among scientific writers. In 2008, the CSE adopted the slogan "CSE: Education, Ethics, and Evidence for Editors (E4)".
A volunteer Board of Directors leads the Council, with the assistance of several committees. CSE is managed by Kellen Company, located in [[Wheat Ridge, Colorado|Wheat Ridge]], [[Colorado]].
== History and organization==
The organization was established in 1957 by the [[National Science Foundation]] and the [[American Institute of Biological Sciences]] as the '''Council of Biology Editors''' (CBE),<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.libraries.psu.edu/psul/lls/students/cse_citation.html | title = CSE Quick Citation Guide | archive-url=https://archive.is/20121214210911/http://www.libraries.psu.edu/psul/lls/students/cse_citation.html |archive-date=2012-12-14 |publisher = [[Pennsylvania State University Libraries]] }}</ref> being renamed the Council of Science Editors, with a broader mission, on January 1, 2000.<ref>[http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3280 History of the Council of Science Editors], 2013, Council of Science Editors.</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://polishedpaper.com/cse-style-guide | title = III. Council of Science Editors (CSE) Style | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061222020412/http://www.monroecc.edu/depts/library/cse.htm |archive-date=2006-12-22 | publisher = [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] | work = Library website }}</ref>
The membership of CSE comprises editorial professionals, mainly in the United States.
As well as providing services and advice online, CSE holds an annual meeting that includes short courses on topics such as journal editorship, publication management, manuscript editing, and journal metrics.
== Policies and endorsements ==
The CSE offers guidance on ethics and practice in scientific publishing. * CSE editorial policy statements ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20100328022842/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/editorial_policies/white_paper.cfm CSE's White Paper on Promoting Integrity in Scientific Journal Publications] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20100618091543/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/editorial_policies/groupauthorarticles.cfm CSE Recommendations for Group-Author Articles in Scientific Journals and Bibliometric Databases] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20100618091555/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/publications/v23n4p111-119.pdf Who's the Author? Problems with Biomedical Authorship, and Some Possible Solutions] * Retreat and task force papers ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20100618082359/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/services/taskforce.cfm Task Force on Science Journals, Poverty, and Human Development] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20071008072928/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/events/retreat_paper_2005-02.pdf Guidance for Journals on Conflict of Interest] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20090906121337/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/services/authorship.cfm Authorship Task Force] * Other statements supported by CSE ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20090831021915/http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/editorial_policies/endorsementofprinciples.cfm ICMJE's Statement on Clinical Trial Registration] ** [http://www.wame.org/wamestmt.htm#geopolitical WAME Policy Statement on Geopolitical Intrusion on Editorial Decisions]
== Publications ==
The CSE publishes a [[style guide]] for [[scientific paper]]s, ''Scientific Style and Format: The CSE Manual for Authors, Editors, and Publishers'', although '''CSE style''' is not as widely used<ref>[http://instr.iastate.libguides.com/content.php?pid=2804&sid=14366 Citation Style Guides], Iowa State University</ref> as some other scientific styles such as [[AMA style]] and [[APA style]]. In 2014, CSE partnered with the [[University of Chicago Press]] to use the successful online platform of the ''[[The Chicago Manual of Style|Chicago Manual of Style]]'' (CMOS) (which provides users with search and personal [[annotation]] of the manual) to publish [http://www.scientificstyleandformat.org/ ''Scientific Style and Format'' online]. As of 2014, it is in the 8th edition.<ref>Scientific Style and Format: The CSE Manual for Authors, Editors, and Publishers, {{ISBN|978-0-226-11649-5}}</ref> The 7th edition was published in 2006<ref>Scientific Style and Format: The CSE Manual for Authors, Editors, and Publishers, {{ISBN|0-9779665-0-X}}, 680 pages.</ref> and the 6th in 1994.<ref>Scientific Style and Format: The CBE Manual for Authors, Editors, and Publishers, 6th edition, 1994, {{ISBN|0-521-47154-0}}</ref> ''Science Editor'' is the quarterly publication of the CSE; after one year, articles are available as open access ([[delayed open access]]).<ref>[http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/publications/science-editor/ Science Editor Archive] Council of Science Editors</ref>
== See also ==
* [[List of style guides]] * ''[[The Chicago Manual of Style]]'' * [[APA style]] * [[AuthorAID]] * [[Association of American Publishers]] * [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] * [[American Institute of Biological Sciences]] * [[Association for Learned and Professional Society Publishers]] * [[American Medical Writers Association]] * [[Board of Editors in the Life Sciences (BELS)]] * [[Committee on Publication Ethics]] * [[European Association of Science Editors]] * [[National Association of Science Writers]] * [[Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts Submitted to Biomedical Journals]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/ www.councilscienceeditors.org], CSE homepage * [http://www.scientificstyleandformat.org/Home.html www.scientificstyleandformat.org], CSE style homepage * [https://twitter.com/CScienceEditors Official Twitter page] * [https://www.facebook.com/CouncilofScienceEditors Official Facebook page] * [https://www.linkedin.com/groups?home=&gid=3103324 Official LinkedIn group]
[[Category:Bibliography]] [[Category:Communications and media organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Professional associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Science writing organizations]]

revision.comment: /* Notable American courtroom artists */ removed link to a different Richard Tomlinson
revision.text:
{{globalize|date=June 2015}} [[File:Accused flanked by attorneys at sentencing, courtroom sketch by Butch Krieger.jpg|thumb|A courtroom sketch of an accused person flanked by two attorneys, drawn in about eight minutes.]]
A '''courtroom sketch''' is an artistic depiction of the proceedings in a [[court]] of law. In many jurisdictions, cameras are not allowed in courtrooms in order to prevent distractions and preserve privacy. This requires news media to rely on [[Sketch (drawing)|sketch]] artists for illustrations of the proceedings.
==Creating courtroom sketches== Courtroom sketch artists attend judicial proceedings as members of the public or as credentialed media depending on the venue and jurisdiction. Judges may require or allow artists to sit in a designated area or they may sit in general public seating. In some jurisdictions, including the [[United Kingdom]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cps.gov.uk/legal/a_to_c/contempt_of_court/|title=Contempt of Court|publisher=Crown Prosecution Service |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=Guardian>{{cite news |author= Guy Dammann |title= A sketchy future for courtroom artists |date=14 November 2006 |publisher=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artblog/2006/nov/14/courtroomartblog |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> and [[Hong Kong]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.hk/blis_ind.nsf/e1bf50c09a33d3dc482564840019d2f4/7889947f4e45de60c825648300287125?OpenDocument |title=Chapter 228, Section 7 – Summary Offences Ordinance |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> courtroom artists are not permitted to sketch proceedings while in court and must create sketches from memory or notes after leaving the courtroom.<ref name=Guardian/>
Courtroom artists can quickly capture a moment on paper and then sell their work to media outlets who would otherwise be denied a visual record of the trial. They may be paid per sketch or on a [[per diem]] commission. Sketches are often sold to television stations, newswire services, newspapers, or the subjects of a sketch.<ref>{{cite news |title=As courtroom sketch artist, she's the people's witness |date=23 February 2009 |publisher=New York Daily News |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/courtroom-sketch-artist-people-witness-article-1.307429 |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Courtroom sketches may also be acquired by institutional archives. The entire set of courtroom sketches related to the [[Lindy Chamberlain]] trial were purchased by the [[National Museum of Australia]] from the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Courtroom drawings sketch Chamberlain's history |author=Anna Morozow |date=25 July 2011 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-07-25/chamberlain-court-sketches-go-on-display/2808280 |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Selected works of American court artists Richard Tomlinson and Elizabeth Williams are held at the Lloyd Sealy Library at the [[John Jay College of Criminal Justice]].<ref name=cuny>{{cite web |title=Classified Information the Lloyd Sealy Library Newsletter |date=Spring 2012 |url=http://www.lib.jjay.cuny.edu/newsletter/spring2012/Spring2012.pdf |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Other collections of courtroom art include the works of [[Howard Brodie]] held in the [[Library of Congress]]<ref name=loc/> and the Collection of the Supreme Court of the United States, which holds selected court artwork from artist Aggie Kenny.<ref name=illustratedcourtroom/>
A courtroom artist must work quickly, particularly during [[arraignment]] hearings where a witness may appear in court for only a few minutes. A television-ready illustration can be produced in that time, and viewed on television after a court proceeding is finished.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sakai |first=Mike |title=Courtroom sketch artist in Loughner case says eyes tell the story |date=16 January 2011 |publisher=East Valley Tribune |url=http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/arizona/article_6bb05b78-202c-11e0-b4df-001cc4c03286.html |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Courtroom artists can be barred from drawing alleged victims of sexual abuse, minors, and jurors or some witnesses in high-profile trials.<ref name=illustratedcourtroom />
==In the United States== [[File:Katy Metz cross examined.jpg|thumb|An 1889 courtroom sketch from the trial of ex-[[Alderman]] Thomas Cleary, which was published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.]] Courtroom sketches in the United States date back as far as the 19th century. Courtroom sketch artists were present for the trial of [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]] and the impeachment of [[Andrew Johnson]].<ref name=coveringcourts>{{cite book |last1=Giles |first1=Robert H. |last2=Snyder |first2=Robert W |title=Covering the courts: free press, fair trials & journalistic performance |year=1999 |publisher=Transaction Publishers |isbn=978-0-7658-0462-4}}</ref><ref name=syracuse>{{cite web |title=Contemporary Courtroom Artists |publisher=Syracuse University |url=http://suart.syr.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/1976-Contemporary-Courtroom-Artists.pdf |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> By the mid-19th century, there were well-known court artists and [[printmaker]]s such as [[George Caleb Bingham]] and David G. Blyth. Sketches during this era were reproduced as engravings in print publications, because photography was not a practical option for courtroom news coverage.<ref name=coveringcourts />
As mass media technology advanced in the early twentieth century, courts began experimenting with allowing photography and radio broadcasts of court proceedings. Following the media "circus" surrounding the trial of [[Richard Hauptmann|Richard Bruno Hauptmann]] for the [[Lindbergh kidnapping]], broadcasts from federal courtrooms were banned by Rule 53 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.<ref name=setonhall>{{cite journal |last=Sarner |first=Joshua |date=Summer 2000 |title=Comment: Justice, Take Two: The Continuing Debate over Cameras in the Courtroom|journal=Seton Hall Constitutional Law Journal |publisher=Seton Hall University |volume=10 |issue= |pages=1053–1083}}</ref> Additionally, the [[American Bar Association]] adopted Judicial Canon 35, which prohibited the use of motion or still [[cameras in the courtroom]] and was codified into law by the majority of states.<ref name=setonhall /> On the other hand, no state or federal court prohibited the publication of courtroom sketches and courtroom sketch artistry continued.<ref name=usvcbs>{{cite court |litigants=United States of America v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. |vol=497 |reporter=F.2d |opinion=102 |pinpoint= |court=United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit |date=11 July 1974 |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref>
In 1973, courtroom artist Aggie Whelan (Kenny) was hired by [[CBS]] to illustrate the [[Gainesville Eight]] trial.<ref name=usvcbs /> The judge presiding over the trial, [[Winston E. Arnow]], ordered that no sketches were to be made in the courtroom and that no sketches of the trial be published, even if those sketches were made outside of the court from memory.<ref name=usvcbs /> In the United States v. Columbia Broadcasting System (1974), the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|Fifth Circuit of Appeals]] overruled the trial judge's order and protected Aggie Whelan's right to create sketches and CBS's right to broadcast courtroom sketches.<ref name=newengland>{{cite journal |last=Cohen |first=Mark C. |date=1974 |title=United States v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.: Courtroom Sketching and the Right to Fair Trial |journal=New England Law Review |publisher=New England School of Law |volume=10 |issue= |pages=541–559}}</ref> The restrictions were too broad and violated both CBS and Whelan's [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights.<ref name=usvcbs />
Television networks began using sketches to illustrate courtroom events during news broadcasts in the 1960s.<ref name=illustratedcourtroom /><ref name=newengland /> As long as the artist arrived on time, and did not disturb the proceedings by making unnecessary noise, their presence was rarely challenged in most jurisdictions.<ref name=newengland /> In jurisdictions where artists were restricted from sketching inside the courtroom, they created sketches from memory.<ref name=coveringcourts /> Courtroom artists including Ida Libby Dengrove protested these restrictions, and gradually courtrooms began allowing sketch artists to work during trials whilst seated in the public gallery.<ref name=coveringcourts />
The reintroduction of camera into courtrooms has been credited with a decline in courtroom sketch artists.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news |title=Artists Brace for Entry Of Cameras Into Courts |date=29 November 1987 |work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/29/nyregion/artists-brace-for-entry-of-cameras-into-courts.html |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=boston>{{cite news |title=Need for courtroom artists fade as cameras move in |author=Michael Tarm |date=28 January 2012 |publisher=Associated Press |url=http://www.boston.com/yourtown/salem/articles/2012/01/28/need_for_courtroom_artists_fade_as_cameras_move_in/ |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> By 1987, courtroom photography was allowed in 44 states.<ref name=nytimes /> While the creation of [[Court tv#As Court TV|Court TV]] and the [[O. J. Simpson murder case]] did cause renewed debate on whether or not courtroom photography should be allowed,<ref name=ohiostate>{{cite journal |last=Paul |first=Angelique M. |date=1997 |title=Turning the Camera on TV: Does Televising Trials Teach Us |journal=Ohio State Law Journal |publisher=Ohio State University |volume=58 |issue= |pages=655–694}}</ref><ref name=loyla>{{cite journal |last=Pugsley |first=Robert A. |title=This Courtroom is not a Television Studio: Why Judge Fujisaki Made the Correct Call in Gagging the Lawyers and Parties, and Banning the Cameras from the O.J. Simpson Civil Case|journal=Loyola of Los Angeles Entertainment Law Journal |publisher=Loyola Marymount University |volume=17 |pages=269–381}}</ref> all 50 states allowed the use of courtroom photography by 2014.<ref name=illustratedcourtroom>{{cite book |last1=Russell |first1=Sue |last2=Williams |first2=Elizabeth |date=2014 |title=The Illustrated Courtroom: 50 Years of Court Art |publisher=CUNY Journalism Press |isbn=1939293529}}</ref>
==Notable American courtroom artists== Notable American courtroom artists include [[Howard Brodie]], Ruben O. Lopez, [[Marguerite Martyn]], Bill Robles, Aggie Whelan Kenny,<ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome Back, Aggie|url=http://courtartist.com/2013/01/welcome-back-aggie.html|website=courtroomartist.com|accessdate=10 July 2015|ref=January 8, 2013}}</ref> [[Elizabeth Williams (artist)|Elizabeth Williams]], Christine Cornell (WNBC and CNN), Art Lien (NBC, [[SCOTUSblog]])<ref>{{cite web|title=This court artist has drawn everyone from Manafort to RBG. Will his craft survive?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/this-court-artist-has-drawn-everyone-from-manafort-to-rbg-will-his-craft-survive/2018/10/12/9ff22fdc-c02f-11e8-be77-516336a26305_story.html|website=www.washingtonpost.com|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>, Marilyn Church (''The New York Times''),<ref>{{cite web|title=Collection of Sketchy Characters|url=https://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/11012/courtroom.html|website=www.loc.gov|publisher=The Library of Congress|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> Richard Tomlinson (WNEW-TV), and [[Joseph W. Papin]] (''The New York Daily News'').<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1842&dat=19760624&id=sRcsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=psgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3974,5034244&hl=en|title=Times Daily - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}</ref>
[[File:Marguerite_Martyn_sketch_of_women_spectators_at_Dora_Doxey_trial_in_1910.png|thumb|left|Reporter-artist [[Marguerite Martyn]] made this sketch of spectators at the murder trial of [[Dora Doxey]], printed in the ''St. Louis Post-Dispatch'' on June 2, 1910.]] [[Joseph W. Papin]] worked for ''[[The New York Daily News]]'' from 1969 to 1992 and covered most of the major U.S. trials during that period of time. Among them, the [[Watergate]] hearings, the [[Patty Hearst]], [[Son of Sam]] (David Berkowitz), [[Pizza Connection Trial|The Pizza Connection]], and the [[Jean Harris]] trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/contemporary-courtroom-artists-anthony-accurso-marilyn-church-stephen-cohen-ida-libby-dengrove-albert-herr-joseph-papin-richard-tomlinson-meryl-treatner-betty-wells-march-3-28-1976-joe-and-emily-lowe-art-gallery-sims-hall-college-of-visual-and-performing-arts-syracuse-university-syracuse-new-york/oclc/2372359|title=Contemporary courtroom artists: Anthony Accurso, Marilyn Church, Stephen Cohen, Ida Libby Dengrove, Albert Herr, Joseph Papin, Richard Tomlinson, Meryl Treatner, Betty Wells : March 3-28, 1976, Joe and Emily Lowe Art Gallery, Sims Hall, College of Visual and Performing Arts, Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York.|first1=Susanne|last1=Owens|first2=M. Jessica|last2=Rowe|first3=Barry M|last3=Winiker|first4=|last4=Joe and Emily Lowe Art Gallery|date=15 August 1976|publisher=The Gallery|via=Open WorldCat}}</ref><ref>COURTROOM ARTISTS The East Hampton Star, "Opinion" section, East Hampton, New York, May 23, 1985</ref>
[[Howard Brodie]] was a courtroom artist whose work included covering the trials of [[Jack Ruby]], [[Sirhan Sirhan]], [[William Calley]], [[Charles Manson]], [[Patty Hearst]], and the [[Chicago Seven]].<ref name=timesbrodie>{{cite news |title=Howard Brodie, 94, Combat and Courtroom Artist, Dies |author=William Grimes |date=25 September 2010 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/24/arts/design/24brodie.html?hpw&_r=1& |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> He primarily worked for the ''[[CBS Evening News]]'' and anchor [[Walter Cronkite]] coined the term "artist-correspondent" to describe his work.<ref name=illustratedcourtroom /><ref name=timesbrodie /> Prior to becoming a courtroom artist, Brodie was a combat artist during World War II and a staff artist for the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''.<ref name=timesbrodie /> Brodie's work is held in the [[Library of Congress]] and he was inducted into the [[Society of Illustrators]] Hall of Fame in 2001.<ref name=loc>{{cite web |title=Search Results: "Brodie, Howard 1915-2010" |publisher=Library of Congress |url=https://www.loc.gov/pictures/related/?fi=name&q=Brodie%2C%20Howard%2C%201915-2010 |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=soi>{{cite web |title=Society of Illustrators: Howard Brodie |publisher=Society of Illustrators |url=http://www.societyillustrators.org/HallofFame.aspx?id=5823&terms=howard+brodie |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref>
Bill Robles is an [[Emmy Award]]-nominated<ref name=illustratedcourtroom /> courtroom artist whose work includes covering the trials of [[Charles Manson]], [[O.J. Simpson]], [[Ted Kaczynski]], [[Timothy McVeigh]], [[Terry Nichols]], [[Richard Ramirez]], [[Rodney King]], and [[Michael Jackson]].<ref name=usatoday>{{cite news |title=Michael Jackson trial raises artist's profile |author=César G. Soriano |date=8 March 2005 |publisher=''[[USA Today]]'' |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2005-03-08-jackson-artist_x.htm |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=wallstreetjournal>{{cite news |title=The Fine Art of Crime |author=Daniel Grant |date=10 August 2010 |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' |url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052748703999304575399472612355204 |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> The first trial Robles covered as a television news courtroom artist was the trial of Manson.<ref name=usatoday />
Aggie Whelan Kenny is a courtroom artist known for her work on covering the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] and trials including [[James Earl Ray]], [[David Berkowitz]], and [[Jerry Sandusky]].<ref name=dailybeast>{{cite news |title=O.J., Martha, Jagger, and Manson: Capturing Celebrities in the Dock |author=Justin Jones |date=29 May 2014 |publisher=The Daily Beast |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/05/29/o-j-martha-jagger-and-manson-capturing-celebrities-in-the-dock.html |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=hudsonreporter>{{cite news |title=Sketching the scene |author=Adriana Rambay Fernández |date=7 February 2013 |publisher=Hudson Reporter |url=http://www.hudsonreporter.com/view/full_story/21643986/article-Sketching-the-scene-Local-gallery-features-courtroom-art-?instance=entertainment |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=nj>{{cite web |title=See drawings of famous courtroom scenes at Hoboken gallery |author=Charles Hack |date=8 February 2013 |publisher=The Jersey Journal |url=http://www.nj.com/jjournal-news/index.ssf/2013/02/see_drawings_of_famous_courtro.html |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Kenny received an [[Emmy Awards|Emmy]] for her work for the ''[[CBS Evening News]]'' on the trials of [[John N. Mitchell]] and [[Maurice Stans]].<ref name=washingtonpost>{{cite news |title=Gagging the Press in the Courtroom |author=Fred Graham |publisher=Washington Post |date=17 November 1974}}</ref> Her work is included in the Collection of the Supreme Court of the United States.<ref name=illustratedcourtroom /> Kenny's sketches of [[Gainesville Eight]] trial led to the court case United States v. Columbia Broadcasting System (1974), which established the right of courtroom artists to create sketches and for those sketches to be broadcast on television.<ref name=newengland />
[[Elizabeth Williams (artist)|Elizabeth Williams]] has covered the trials [[John DeLorean]], [[Martha Stewart]], [[John Gotti]], [[Michael Milken]], [[Bernard Madoff]], [[Dominique Strauss-Khan]], and the [[Faisal Shahzad|Times Square Bomber]].<ref name=nypress>{{cite news |title=Reporting By Drawing |author=Daniel Fitzsimmons |publisher=New York Press |date=6 November 2013 |url=http://nypress.com/reporting-by-drawing/ |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=wsj>{{cite news |title=Live Blog: Sandusky Waives Right to Hearing |author=John W. Miller |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' |date=13 December 2011 |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2011/12/13/live-blog-sandusky-hearing/ |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> She is best known for her coverage of [[white-collar crime|white-collar criminals]] tried in New York City.<ref name=nytimesew>{{cite news |title=Capturing on Canvas the Downfall of Wall Street’s Criminals |author=Alexandra Stevenson |publisher=The New York Times |date=14 April 2014 |url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/04/14/capturing-on-canvas-the-downfall-of-wall-streets-criminals/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&emc=eta1&_r=2 |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Her sketches depicting the [[Sean Bell shooting incident|Sean Bell]] trial are held by the Lloyd Sealy Library at the [[John Jay College of Criminal Justice]].<ref name="cuny"/>
Actor [[Terry Crews]] stated in an appearance on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live]]'' that his first job in the entertainment industry was as the courtroom sketch artist for [[WJRT]] in [[Flint, Michigan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZKmsx_vv68k|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Journalism}} *[[:Category:Courtroom sketch artists]] *[[sketch (drawing)|Sketch]] *[[History of journalism]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Courtroom drawings}} *[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/inside-story-captured-for-posterity-433243.html A British perspective] *[http://www.ironicsans.com/2008/03/the_other_art_of_courtroom_ske.html An American perspective] *[http://www.nydailynews.com/lifestyle/2008/02/24/2008-02-24_as_courtroom_sketch_artist_shes_the_peop.html A personal perspective]
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Courtroom Sketch}} [[Category:Art genres]] [[Category:Court reporting]] [[Category:Courtroom sketch artists]] [[Category:Journalism]] [[Category:Journalism occupations]]

{{Multiple issues |{{update|inaccurate=yes|date=July 2012}}{{refimprove|date=July 2012}}{{undue|date=July 2012}}}} [[File:20150319-OC-LSC-0194 (16682627630).jpg|thumb|upright|A culinary student at [[Gwinnett Technical College]] in [[Lawrenceville, Georgia]], 2015]] '''Culinary arts''', in which ''[[wikt:culinary|culinary]]'' means "related to [[cooking]]", are the arts of preparation, cooking and presentation of [[food]], usually in the form of [[meal]]s. People working in this field – especially in establishments such as [[restaurant]]s – are commonly called "[[chef]]s" or "[[Cook (profession)|cooks]]", although, at its most general, the terms "culinary artist" and "[[wikt:Culinarian|culinarian]]" are also used. [[Table manners]] ("the table arts") are sometimes referred to as a culinary art.
Expert Culinarians are required to have knowledge of [[food science]], [[nutrition]] and [[Diet (nutrition)|diet]] and are responsible for preparing meals that are as pleasing to the eye as well as to the [[palate]]. After restaurants, their primary places of work include [[delicatessen]]s and relatively large institutions such as hotels and hospitals.
==Origins== The Culinary Arts, in the [[Western world]], as a craft and later as a field of study, began to evolve at the end of the [[Renaissance]] period. Prior to this, chefs worked in castles, cooking for kings and queens, as well as their families, guests, and other workers of the castle. As [[Monarchy|Monarchical rule]] became phased out as a modality, the chefs took their craft to [[hotel|inns and hotels]]. From here, the craft evolved into a field of study.
A great deal of the study of Culinary Arts in Europe was organized by [[Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin]], a man famous for his quote "Tell me what you eat, and I will tell you what you are," which has since been mistranslated and oversimplified into "You are what you eat." Other people helped to parse out the different parts of food science and gastronomy. Over time, increasingly deeper and more detailed studies into foods and the Culinary Arts has led to a greater wealth of knowledge.
In Asia, a similar path led to a separate study of the Culinary Arts, which later essentially merged with the Western counterpart. In the modern international marketplace, there is no longer a distinct divide between Western and Eastern foods. Culinary Arts students today, generally speaking, are introduced to the different cuisines of many different cultures from around the world.
Today, there are thousands of Culinary Arts schools around the world. Additionally, most universities, as well as many smaller tertiary schools like community colleges, offer some type of Culinary Arts Degree, which is technically a Bachelor of Arts Degree.
==Professional study== Modern Culinary Arts students study many different aspects of food. Specific areas of study include butchery, chemistry and thermodynamics, visual presentation, food safety, human nutrition and physiology, international history, the manufacture of food items (such as the milling of wheat into flour or the refining of cane plants into crystalline sucrose), and many others.
Training in culinary arts is possible in most countries around the world. Usually at tertiary level (university). With institutions government funded, privately funded or commercial.
== See also == {{portal|Cooking|Cuisines|Food}} {{Columns |colwidth=18.0em | col1 = * [[American Dietetic Association]] * [[Foodpairing]] * [[Chef]] * [[Cuisine]] * [[Food studies]] | col2 = * [[Fooding]] * [[Gastronomy]] * [[Gourmet Library and museum]] * [[Hospitality industry]] * [[Restaurant]] }}

Culinary Arts information RSS. N.p.,nd. web.17 Sept.2013 * "History of Culinary Arts." Culinary Arts Information RSS. N.p,. web. 17 Sept.2013 * "The Culinary Timeline." The Culinary Timeline.
