Presale reservations were expected to begin in March 2005.<ref name=LVS-Club/> At the time of its announcement, the project was reported to cost $400 million to construct.<ref name=LVRJ-Club>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Developer plans condominium project for locals|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-31-Mon-2005/business/25760479.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 31, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051215155216/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-31-Mon-2005/business/25760479.html|archivedate=December 15, 2005}}</ref> The cost was later reported as being $250 million.<ref name=Club-Feb15/>
The project received final approval in February 2005.<ref name=Club-Feb17>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=60-story building to replace historic railroad cottages|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/feb/17/60-story-building-to-replace-historic-railroad-cot/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 17, 2005}}</ref> Several historic railroad cottages located on the property were expected to be relocated.<ref name=Club-Feb15>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=Cottages may make way for downtown high rise|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/feb/15/cottages-may-make-way-for-downtown-high-rise/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 15, 2005}}</ref><ref name=Club-Feb17/> The tower, expected to be 702 feet high, was one of the taller high-rise projects to be approved for downtown Las Vegas.<ref name=Club-Feb17/> Sales began in October 2005, at which point the starting price had increased into the $400,000 range because of rises in steel, concrete and labor costs. As of February 2006, the cottages remained on the site, with little progress on Club Renaissance. Gilles Pageau, a Canadian developer and the uncle of Philippe Pageau-Goyette, said he had invested $60 million of his money into the project and that he had been offered an additional $400 million from various banks to cover the construction costs. Pageau said at the time that the project would still be built.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Club Renaissance will get built, developer vows|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Feb-13-Mon-2006/business/5772051.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 13, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060216044725/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Feb-13-Mon-2006/business/5772051.html|archivedate=February 16, 2006}}</ref>
In February 2007, Goodman gave the developers two weeks to demonstrate to the Las Vegas City Council that the project was nearing construction; otherwise, he said the approval for the project would be revoked. Leanord Mussina, a spokesman for the project, had told the City Council, "We're just a victim of construction costs. Financing has dried up to a large extent for Las Vegas. We're redesigning, trying to value engineer, to do something affordable. We're in negotiations with some large construction companies to joint venture at this point, because that's the only way to finance it." Mussina estimated that the project could take up to a year before construction started, to which Goodman responded, "I'm not interested in a year. I've been to three groundbreakings there so far and haven't seen ground broke." Approximately $8 million or $9 million had already been spent on the project up to that point.<ref name=LVS-Feb11-2007>{{cite news|last=McGrath Schwartz|first=David|title=Council pressures downtown builders|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Feb-11-Sun-2007/news/12515962.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 11, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070404174743/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Feb-11-Sun-2007/news/12515962.html|archivedate=April 4, 2007}}</ref>
The City Council ultimately granted the project a six-month extension. At the time, part of the property that was to be used for the project was in foreclosure.<ref name=LVRJ-Feb22-2007>{{cite news|last=McGrath Schwartz|first=David|title=Las Vegas City Council grants extensions to two development projects downtown|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Feb-22-Thu-2007/news/12747215.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 22, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070301180211/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Feb-22-Thu-2007/news/12747215.html|archivedate=March 1, 2007}}</ref><ref name=LVS-Feb23-2007>{{cite news|title=City Council sees flip side of 'flipper' argument|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2007/feb/23/city-council-sees-flip-side-of-flipper-argument/|accessdate=February 26, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 23, 2007}}</ref> In March 2007, the project was purchased out of foreclosure by Los Angeles architect Mark Vaghei and engineer Nabih Yousseff for nearly $3.5 million. The pair began redesigning the project to be smaller.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Renaissance gets renaissance|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/archive/search|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 23, 2007|subscription=yes}}</ref> Club Renaissance ultimately did not materialize.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=High-rise plans go flat in Las Vegas|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/high-rise-plans-go-flat-las-vegas|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 2, 2009}}</ref>
===Fontainebleau Las Vegas=== {{Main article|The Drew Las Vegas}} Located on the Las Vegas Strip and originally known as Fontainebleau Las Vegas. Construction began in 2007, and the resort was to include a casino, 2,871 hotel rooms, and 1,018 condominium units.<ref>{{cite news|last=Knightly|first=Arnold M.|title=Fontainebleau, what's really up with you?|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/fontainebleau-whats-really-you|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 17, 2008}}</ref> Construction on the $2.9 billion project ceased in 2009, the year of its planned opening. Investment firms [[Steve Witkoff|Witkoff Group]] and [[New Valley LLC]] purchased the unfinished resort in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Segall|first1=Eli|last2=Velotta|first2=Richard N.|title=Fontainebleau on Las Vegas Strip sells for $600M|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/fontainebleau-on-las-vegas-strip-sells-for-600m/|accessdate=August 29, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 29, 2017}}</ref> In 2018, Witkoff and [[Marriott International]] announced a partnership to open the renamed project as The Drew Las Vegas in 2020. The resort will include a casino and three hotels totaling nearly 4,000 rooms, with the condominium aspect removed from the project.<ref name=NewName>{{cite news|last=Segall|first=Eli|title=Fontainebleau on Las Vegas Strip has new name and opening date|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/fontainebleau-on-las-vegas-strip-has-new-name-and-opening-date/|accessdate=13 February 2018|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=12 February 2018}}</ref>
===Icon=== In November 2004, [[Jorge M. Pérez]] and [[The Related Companies]] were planning Icon, a twin-tower condominium project to be built on {{convert|4.5|acre|abbr=on}} of property,<ref name=Familiar/> located on the Las Vegas Strip at the northeast corner of Convention Center Drive.<ref name=LVS-Mar11-2005/> The land was located east of a [[Ross Stores|Ross]] department store,<ref name=Familiar/> and the project would be built behind the store.<ref name=LVS-Mar11-2005/> Related purchased the vacant land in January 2004, at a cost of $15 million. The land had previously been owned by [[Luke Brugnara]], who also owned the adjacent [[Silver City Casino]].<ref name=Familiar>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Icon developer familiar with high-rise projects|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-24-Wed-2004/business/25328642.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 24, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041204082449/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-24-Wed-2004/business/25328642.html|archivedate=December 4, 2004}}</ref> Initially, Icon was to include two 47-story towers, standing 500 feet, with a total of 502 luxury condominiums, all facing the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=Familiar/> Two-thirds of the project's units would include views on both sides of the buildings for views of the Las Vegas Strip and nearby mountains.<ref name=Beyond61/> Unit prices would start at $500,000. The $30 million project was designed by [[Bernardo Fort Brescia]] of [[Arquitectonica]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Las Vegas' high-rise frenzy familiar to Canadian architect|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2005/May-21-Sat-2005/business/1760503.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 21, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051211014846/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2005/May-21-Sat-2005/business/1760503.html|archivedate=December 11, 2005}}</ref><ref name=Familiar/> which teamed up with interior designer [[Yabu Pushelberg]] for the project.<ref name=Familiar/> Construction on the first tower was to begin in 2005, with work on the second tower scheduled to begin after the first was completed.<ref name=Beyond61>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Related plans beyond 61 acres|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/nov/23/related-plans-beyond-61-acres/|accessdate=March 7, 2018|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=November 23, 2004}}</ref>
By April 2005, the project had been redesigned after Lorenzo Doumani, developer of the adjacent [[#Majestic Las Vegas|Majestic Las Vegas]], raised concerns about the Icon blocking views for tenants at the Majestic, among other issues. By that time, M.J. Dean had signed on as the general contractor for Icon, and the first tower was expected to take 18 to 24 months to construct. At that point, the towers were expected to be 48 stories high, with a total of 514 units.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Related keeps neighbors in mind with Icon design|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-02-Sat-2005/business/1017868.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 2, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050408042620/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-02-Sat-2005/business/1017868.html|archivedate=April 8, 2005}}</ref> The Clark County Commission approved Icon in April 2005, despite objections from Doumani, who then [[Majestic Las Vegas#Icon lawsuits|filed lawsuits]] against Related.<ref>{{cite news|last=Curran|first=Stephen|title=Developer to sue over shadows|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/apr/07/developer-to-sue-over-shadows/|accessdate=March 9, 2018|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=April 7, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Towers get approval, but must adhere to rendering|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-07-Thu-2005/business/1079802.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 7, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060101013957/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-07-Thu-2005/business/1079802.html|archivedate=January 1, 2006}}</ref><ref name=Mandate/> Later that month, a lawsuit was filed against Related by Sasson Hallier Properties LLC, developer of [[#Panorama Towers|Panorama Towers]]. The two companies had previously negotiated a possible joint venture for the Panorama Towers project, and Sasson Hallier provided various database information – including contracts, financials, and marketing information – to Related as part of the negotiations. Ultimately, negotiations failed, and Sasson Hallier alleged that Related kept the database information to develop its Icon project.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Lawsuit alleges developer wrongly used information|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/apr/25/lawuit-alleges-developer-wrongly-used-information/|accessdate=March 9, 2018|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=April 25, 2005}}</ref>
In January 2006, Related announced the cancellation of Icon despite that buyers had signed contracts for most of the project's 514 units. Related stated, "In the several months needed to resolve lawsuits and finally be in a position to break ground, construction prices had increased so drastically that after pursuing every possible way to move forward, Related was unable to build Icon based on original pricing without seriously impacting the integrity of the development." A decrease in high-rise sales was also a factor in the cancellation.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2006/jan/07/loss-of-an-icon-a-threat-to-market/|title= Loss of an Icon a threat to market|last= Shubinski|first= Jennifer|date= January 7, 2006|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 9, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=High-rise market taking some hits: Icon latest project to fall from skies|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-07-Sat-2006/business/5248008.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 7, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060111101546/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-07-Sat-2006/business/5248008.html|archivedate=January 11, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Icon News|url=http://www.vegastodayandtomorrow.com/icon.htm|website=VegasTodayAndTomorrow.com|accessdate=March 9, 2018|date=November 4, 2007}}</ref> In May 2006, a lawsuit was filed by buyers against Related, stating that the company had no right to cancel purchase agreements for Icon's units.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Cancellation of Icon Towers brings lawsuit from buyers|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-01-Thu-2006/business/7709454.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 1, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060613202346/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-01-Thu-2006/business/7709454.html|archivedate=June 13, 2006}}</ref>
===Krystle Sands=== On April 1, 2004, reservations opened for floors 4 to 38 of a 45-story, 510-foot condominium-hotel tower known as Krystle Sands. The project was officially announced in May 2004 by F.W. "Freddie" Schinz, a Florida developer.<ref name=LVS-May7-2004/><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Office building going up in Southern Highlands|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/May-10-Mon-2004/business/23817328.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 10, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050121122328/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/May-10-Mon-2004/business/23817328.html|archivedate=January 21, 2005}}</ref> The Krystle Sands project was to replace the 105-room [[Algiers Hotel]], located on a 3.6-acre site on the Las Vegas Strip, adjacent to the [[#Turnberry Place|Turnberry Place]] complex and to the former site of the [[El Rancho Hotel and Casino]]. At the time of the announcement, 70 percent of the project's 600 units had been reserved.<ref name=LVS-May7-2004/>
Units would range from {{convert|852|sqft|abbr=on}} to {{convert|1329|sqft|abbr=on}}, and would range in price from $400,000 to more than $700,000. Although the tower was to be 45 stories high, it would skip the 13th floor.<ref name=LVS-May7-2004/> The tower's penthouses, starting at $1 million,<ref name=LVRJ-Mar23-2005/> would be located from floors 39 to 44, and would range from {{convert|2400|sqft|abbr=on}} to more than {{convert|3000|sqft|abbr=on}}. Restaurants and retail were planned for the tower's first and second floors. The third floor was to consist of a recreation center and pool for condominium owners and renters. A rooftop restaurant was also planned. JMA Architecture Studios was the architect. Perini Construction Company was to be the general contractor. Krystle Sands was to cost $400 million,<ref name=LVS-May7-2004/> and was to begin construction in October 2004,<ref name=LVRJ-Mar24-2005/> with an opening in summer 2006.<ref name=LVS-May7-2004>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Algiers deal to make way for condo project on Strip|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/may/07/algiers-deal-to-make-way-for-condo-project-on-stri/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=May 7, 2004}}</ref>
Schinz paid more than $26.2 million for the land, and closed on the deal in July 2004.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Trump in new LV condo deal|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/jul/30/trump-in-new-lv-condo-deal/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=July 30, 2004}}</ref> The project was to be handled by Krystle Sands LLC, a limited liability company formed by Schinz in Florida. The company name was later changed to Krystle Towers LLC.<ref name=LVS-Apr4-2005/> In March 2005, Schinz sold Krystle Towers LLC and the property for $97 million to Turnberry Associates, which owned the Turnberry Place complex and the former land of the El Rancho.<ref name=LVRJ-Mar23-2005>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Valley high-rise project 'dead in the water'|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Mar-23-Wed-2005/business/925100.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 23, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050324204727/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Mar-23-Wed-2005/business/925100.html|archivedate=March 24, 2005}}</ref><ref name=LVRJ-Mar24-2005>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Turnberry confirms land buy|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Mar-24-Thu-2005/business/937009.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 24, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051213052140/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Mar-24-Thu-2005/business/937009.html|archivedate=December 13, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/mar/23/business-briefs-for-march-23-2005/|title=Business briefs for March 23, 2005|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=March 23, 2005|accessdate=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name=LVS-Apr4-2005>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Cancellation of condo project spurs lawsuits|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/apr/04/cancellation-of-condo-project-spurs-lawsuits/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=April 4, 2005}}</ref> To avoid paying a [[real estate transfer tax]], Turnberry purchased the Krystle Sands project in addition to the property on which it was to be built.<ref name=LVRJ-Jun3-2006/> Turnberry announced the cancellation of Krystle Sands to buyers in a letter on March 25, 2005, stating that it was unable to receive construction financing to build the project.<ref name=LVS-Apr4-2005/>
Shortly after the cancellation was announced, some buyers of the project's condominium units filed five lawsuits against Schinz, Krystle Sands LLC, Krystle Towers LLC, and Fidelity National Title Agency of Nevada. One lawsuit sought class-action status. Each lawsuit alleged that Schinz never planned to build the tower and was in the process of seeking a buyer for the property while selling the project's 600 units, in an alleged attempt to make what would ultimately become a $70 million profit. Other claims in the lawsuits included allegations of fraud, deceptive trade practices and civil conspiracy. Plaintiffs sought at least $70 million in damages, as well as the return of escrow money to the buyers. One lawsuit alleged that Turnberry had made false statements regarding its reason for cancelling Krystle Sands, noting that four days earlier, Turnberry had announced that it received construction financing for a separate 636-unit tower at its Turnberry Place complex.<ref name=LVS-Apr4-2005/>
A class action lawsuit consisting of 150 buyers was underway by June 2006, alleging that Turnberry had an obligation to provide condominium units to buyers who signed purchase and sale agreements and placed 10 percent of the purchase price in escrow. Turnberry stated that all deposits made on Krystle Sands units had been returned and that the company had no intention of building the project. A lawyer representing the group alleged that Turnberry lied to buyers about being unable to obtain construction financing for Krystle Sands as part of an attempt to build the [[#Fontainebleau Resort Las Vegas|Fontainebleau resort]] on the property: "They had to figure a way to lie to buyers and not tell the truth that they're going to jettison the project to build Fountainbleu [sic]." The case was expected to go to trial in March 2007.<ref name=LVRJ-Jun3-2006>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Krystal Sands buyers file lawsuit over failed project|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-03-Sat-2006/business/7758674.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 3, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629140633/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-03-Sat-2006/business/7758674.html|archivedate=June 29, 2006}}</ref>
===Las Ramblas=== {{Main article|Las Ramblas Resort}} Announced in March 2005, as a joint project between Centra Properties and [[The Related Companies]].<ref name=LVS-Mar11-2005>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/mar/11/centra-thinks-big/|title= Centra thinks big|last= Shubinski|first= Jennifer|date= March 11, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> The $3 billion Las Ramblas project was planned as a {{convert|25|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} mixed-use complex that would have included 11 high-rise buildings, which would be used for hotel rooms and condominiums.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/aug/29/clooney-joins-cast-of-investors-in-lv-project/|title= Clooney joins cast of investors in LV project|last= Benston|first= Liz|date= August 29, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2010/jan/08/condo-woes-link-lv-miami/|title= Condo woes link LV, Miami|last= Wargo|first= Buck|date= January 8, 2010|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> with a total of 4,400 units.<ref name=glitz>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-30-Tue-2005/business/3100790.html|title= Puttin' on the glitz: Actor, nightclub magnate invest in Las Ramblas|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= August 30, 2005|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060104063052/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-30-Tue-2005/business/3100790.html|archive-date= January 4, 2006}}</ref> The complex, designed by Arquitectonica,<ref name="hit-snag"/> would also include a small casino and up to {{convert|500000|sqft|abbr=on}} of retail stores.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/aug/30/dress-code-idea-for-planned-casino-could-get-cold-/|title= Dress code idea for planned casino could get cold shoulder|last= Benston|first= Liz|date= August 30, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/news/clooney-rolls-the-dice-on-vegas/|title= Clooney Rolls The Dice On Vegas|last= Montopoli|first= Brian|date= August 29, 2005|publisher= CBS|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> Las Ramblas was to replace the 996-unit Harbor Island apartments, as well as 14 [[Duplex (building)|four-plex]] buildings, all located east of the Las Vegas Strip on Harmon Avenue.<ref name=LVS-Mar11-2005/> In August 2005, actor [[George Clooney]] and nightclub developer [[Rande Gerber]] announced that they would invest in the project.<ref name=glitz/> Because of a declining market and rising construction costs, Las Ramblas was cancelled in 2006, and the property was subsequently sold to Edge Resorts, which planned to construct a [[boutique hotel]] district to accompany their proposed [[#W Las Vegas|W resort]], located on adjacent land.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-05-Mon-2006/business/7782932.html|title= Clooney project is sold: Edge Resorts plans boutique hotel district at Las Ramblas site|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= June 5, 2006|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060629140710/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-05-Mon-2006/business/7782932.html|archive-date= June 29, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nbcnews.com/id/13146745/ns/business-real_estate/t/george-clooney-backed-condo-project-sold/|title= George Clooney-backed condo project sold|last= |first= |date= June 5, 2006|publisher= NBC|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> Las Ramblas was to begin construction in September 2006, with its first phase scheduled to open in June 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/norm-clarke/least-clooney-still-has-his-shirt|title= At least Clooney still has his shirt|last= Clarke|first= Norm|date= June 8, 2007|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===Las Vegas Plaza=== {{Main article|Las Vegas Plaza}} Las Vegas Plaza was planned as a multibillion-dollar resort on the site of the demolished New Frontier hotel and casino. The project was to include 2,600 condominium units. The project never materialized, and in 2014, the property was sold to Crown Resorts, which planned to build the [[Alon Las Vegas]] on the site.
===Liberty Tower / Monument / Stratorise=== Liberty Tower was announced in June 2004,<ref name=Liberty/> as a 21-story building to be built on {{convert|0.68|acre|abbr=on}} at 1801 South Las Vegas Boulevard,<ref name=LVS-Aug5-2004/> at the southern end of downtown Las Vegas.<ref name=Liberty/> The project would be located north of the [[Stratosphere Las Vegas|Stratosphere tower]]<ref name=LVSaug/> and near the [[18b The Las Vegas Arts District|Las Vegas Arts District]],<ref name=Liberty/> on land that was purchased for $900,000.<ref name=LVS-Dec16-2005/> The project was designed by JMA Architecture Studios and was to be developed by Harvard Securities of Australia. Groundbreaking was expected by November 2004, with completion occurring a year and a half later at a cost of $35 million.<ref name=Liberty>{{cite news|last=Negron|first=Sito|title=Residential downtown Las Vegas tower is planned|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/jun/28/residential-downtown-las-vegas-tower-is-planned/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 28, 2004}}</ref>
In August 2004, the 21-story project was approved by the Las Vegas City Council to include 18 condominium units, 116 apartments, and {{convert|2200|sqft|abbr=on}} of ground-level retail space.<ref name=LVS-Aug5-2004>{{cite news|last=Squires|first=Michael|title=Council approves two towers|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Aug-05-Thu-2004/news/24469090.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 5, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041030060428/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Aug-05-Thu-2004/news/24469090.html|archivedate=October 30, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Former senator hopes to revitalize Meadows Village|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/aug/05/former-senator-hopes-to-revitalize-meadows-village/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 5, 2004}}</ref> That month, it was announced that Australian developers Joseph Di Mauro and Victor Altomare would finance the project, which they also planned to do for [[#The Summit / Ivana Las Vegas|The Summit]].<ref name=LVRJaug>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Aug-21-Sat-2004/business/24582121.html|title=Duo sets sights sky high |last=Jones|first=Chris|date=August 21, 2004|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041107053438/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Aug-21-Sat-2004/business/24582121.html|archive-date=November 7, 2004}}</ref> By January 2005, the closed [[Holy Cow Casino and Brewery]] (the planned future site of The Summit) had been converted into a $1 million sales office for Liberty Tower. At that time, construction on the project was expected to begin in July 2005, with a cost of $100 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-27-Thu-2005/business/25735166.html|title=923-foot condo OK'd for Strip|last=Smith|first=Hubble|date=January 27, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051116171958/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-27-Thu-2005/business/25735166.html|archive-date=November 16, 2005}}</ref>
Construction of Liberty Tower never began. In December 2005, Altomare sold the property for $5.5 million to Stratorise South, a [[limited liability company]] based in Nevada.<ref name=LVS-Dec16-2005/> That month, plans were announced for a $105 million condominium project called Monument to be built on the property. The project was to be 22 stories, with 236 units, and was to be developed by Constellation Property Group, an Australia-based company owned by Eugene Marchese, with financing by partner David Rifkind.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Australian group buys parcel slated for condos: Plans call for 22-story, 236-unit complex called Monument|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-17-Sat-2005/business/4847272.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 17, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051224024126/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-17-Sat-2005/business/4847272.html|archivedate=December 24, 2005}}</ref> By August 2006, a new project known as Stratorise was being planned for the property. The project would stand 517 feet, and would include 45 stories. In September 2006, a hearing on the proposed project was delayed until November 1, 2006, at the request of the owner.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=David|title=45-story tower planned in area where city rejected height limits|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/archive/search|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 26, 2006|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hearing on high-rise delayed|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/archive/search|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 7, 2006|subscription=yes}}</ref>
===Majestic Las Vegas=== {{Main|Majestic Las Vegas}} Majestic Las Vegas was announced in February 2004, and was to be built on the property occupied by the [[La Concha Motel]] on the Las Vegas Strip. Majestic Las Vegas initially was to consist of a 42-story tower,<ref>{{cite news|title=Developer unveils plan for $250 million Strip resort|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/feb/19/developer-unveils-plan-for-250-million-strip-resor/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=[[Las Vegas Sun]]|date=February 19, 2004}}</ref> although the project later went through several redesigns, before being cancelled in 2007.<ref name=Mandate>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Developer: Construction costs mandate second Majestic tower|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/sep/23/developer-construction-costs-mandate-second-majest/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 23, 2005}}</ref><ref name=Vegas>{{cite web|title=Conrad / Waldorf News|url=http://www.vegastodayandtomorrow.com/majestic.htm|publisher=VegasTodayAndTomorrow.com|date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===One Las Vegas / Vegas 888=== In August 2004, Chris DelGuidice, who was developing [[#Vegas Grand|Vegas Grand]] through his Del American company, announced plans for a second project to be known as One Las Vegas. The project would include a 565-foot 50-story condominium tower with 542 units, to be built at a cost of $500 million on 10 acres of land on Flamingo Road, east of the [[Palms Casino Resort]].<ref name=LVRJ-Aug6-2004>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=CEO ready for bigger enterprise near Palms|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Aug-06-Fri-2004/business/24477171.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 6, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041030001803/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Aug-06-Fri-2004/business/24477171.html|archivedate=October 30, 2004}}</ref><ref name=LVRJ-Sep16-2004>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Las Vegas adds to credentials as high-rise haven|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Sep-16-Thu-2004/business/24781442.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 16, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041130034137/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Sep-16-Thu-2004/business/24781442.html|archivedate=November 30, 2004}}</ref> DelGuidice negotiated for a year and a half to purchase the property.<ref name=LVRJ-Sep16-2004/>
Early design plans included a 400-foot waterfall, rooftop hot tubs, a dance floor, a gourmet grocer, restaurants, a {{convert|20000|sqft|abbr=on}} pool with cabanas, a {{convert|15000|sqft|abbr=on}} health spa on the 35th floor, valet and housekeeping services, 24-hour concierge, a pet park, and a business center. Sales were expected to begin in early 2005, with prices starting at $500,000 and exceeding $10 million.<ref name=LVRJ-Sep16-2004/> Groundbreaking was reported to be a year away.<ref name=LVRJ-Aug6-2004/> The following month, construction was scheduled to begin in summer 2005.<ref>{{cite news|title=Condo tower plans detailed|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/sep/15/condo-tower-plans-detailed/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 15, 2004}}</ref> The project was to be financed by Lehman Brothers,<ref name=MarketLookingUp/> with a loan of up to $79.45 million.<ref name=Lehman888/> Lehman Brothers also financed Vegas Grand.<ref name=MarketLookingUp>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Housing Market: Looking Up|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-14-Sun-2004/business/25124165.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 14, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041116032437/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-14-Sun-2004/business/25124165.html|archivedate=November 16, 2004}}</ref>
Del American closed escrow on the property in January 2005, at a cost of $50 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=LV key expansion market for Panda Express|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-10-Mon-2005/business/25611008.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 10, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051213192225/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-10-Mon-2005/business/25611008.html|archivedate=December 13, 2005}}</ref> In February 2005, Amland Development took legal action against Del American to continue using the name for its own condominium project, also known as [[#One Las Vegas|One Las Vegas]]. Amland Development won the right to use the name.<ref name=AmlandOne2/><ref name=AmlandOne>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Vegas Grand could head higher after getting permit|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-26-Mon-2005/business/5041712.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 26, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051229181536/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-26-Mon-2005/business/5041712.html|archivedate=December 29, 2005}}</ref> In November 2005, Del American announced that the project would be named Vegas 888.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vegas 888 - The Ultimate Resort Condominium Residence to Launch in the Heart of Las Vegas|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/vegas-888---the-ultimate-resort-condominium-residence-to-launch-in-the-heart-of-las-vegas-55722202.html|publisher=Del American|accessdate=March 16, 2017|date=November 28, 2005}}</ref> The sales office for Vegas 888 closed in July 2006, at which point the property was reportedly for sale.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Spanish View Towers work halted; Vegas 888 shuts sales office|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jul-15-Sat-2006/business/8504642.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 15, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060717163146/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jul-15-Sat-2006/business/8504642.html|archivedate=July 17, 2006}}</ref> Approximately $250 million worth of condominium units had been presold, with approximately $75 million spent on the project, most of which came from Lehman Brothers.<ref name=Lehman888/> In August 2006, Del American announced intentions to instead build a mixed-use resort, hotel and casino on the property.<ref name=Apace/>
The new project remained un-built. In 2007, the property was foreclosed and acquired by Lehman Brothers. Christopher Beavor, a Las Vegas investor, purchased the property in October 2016, at a cost of $13.5 million. Beavor's initial, unfinalized plans included retail space, a five-story apartment complex, and a hotel, with construction expected to begin in six to seven months.<ref name=Lehman888>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/economic-development/nongaming-hotel-planned-west-vegas-strip-site-sold-discount-boom-years|title= Nongaming hotel planned west of Vegas Strip on site sold at discount from boom years|last= Segall|first= Eli|date= October 4, 2016|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===Opus Las Vegas / unnamed mixed-use project=== The Opus Las Vegas was approved in November 2004,<ref name=LVS-Mar28-2005/> and was announced on March 25, 2005, at a conference that was related to high-rise development and was held at the [[Bellagio (resort)|Bellagio resort]] on the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=LVRJ-Mar26-2005/> The $550 million project would have consisted of two 50-story towers with 350 condominium units each,<ref name=LVS-Mar28-2005/> for a total of 700.<ref name=LVRJ-Mar26-2005/> The project, to be developed by The Congress Group of Boston, was planned for a {{convert|4.4|acre|abbr=on}} property that was presently occupied by the city's [[Scandia Amusements|Scandia Family Fun Center]],<ref name=LVRJ-Mar26-2005/> located west of the Las Vegas Strip at 2900 Sirius Avenue.<ref name=Sirius/> Up to that point, The Congress Group had spent a year determining construction costs. Scandia and The Congress Group agreed to delay the initial escrow closing date of May 2005, so that final costs for the new project could be completed. As part of the agreement, the Scandia fun center would remain open through the summer, its busiest period, before its scheduled closing date on September 6, 2005.<ref name=LVRJ-Mar26-2005/><ref name=LVS-Mar28-2005/>
At the time of the announcement, the property was in the process of being sold by Highrise Partners to The Congress Group for an undisclosed amount of money, with escrow expected to close in September 2005. Groundbreaking was expected to occur in the first quarter of 2006, with the first units available for occupancy in spring 2008. Opus Las Vegas would have featured 1,400 parking spaces spread across four levels, along with {{convert|20000|sqft|abbr=on}} of residential retail stores. A {{convert|3|acre|abbr=on}} pool would be located on the property's six-story deck. Floor plans would have ranged from {{convert|800|sqft|abbr=on}} {{convert|4200|sqft|abbr=on}}, and would have come in one-, two-, and three-bedroom designs, while the top two floors would be occupied by two-story penthouses.<ref name=LVRJ-Mar26-2005>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Mar-26-Sat-2005/business/957501.html|title= Strip family center sold: Developers plan high-rise condo at Scandia site|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= March 26, 2005|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050328002455/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Mar-26-Sat-2005/business/957501.html|archive-date=March 28, 2005}}</ref><ref name=LVS-Mar28-2005>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/mar/28/expert-high-rise-shakeout-is-likely/|title= Expert: High-rise shakeout is likely|last= Shubinski|first= Jennifer|date= March 28, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> Prices would have ranged from $200,000 to more than $4 million.<ref name=LVS-Mar28-2005/> Developer Michael Jabara said the project would offer "a metropolitan lifestyle for people who really want it all, great views, easy access to nearby neighborhood amenities, but at the same time it's an urban project."<ref name=LVS-Mar28-2005/>
In June 2005, Scandia said their fun center would remain open as the property had not been sold.<ref name=Sirius>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jun/03/columnist-susan-snyder-life-isnt-too-serious-on-si/|title= Life isn't too serious on Sirius|last= Snyder|first= Susan|date= June 3, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> On September 7, 2005,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://sandgate.co.clark.nv.us/assrrealprop/ParcelHistory.aspx?instance=pcl2&parcel=16208702002|title= Parcel Ownership History|publisher= Clark County Assessor's Office|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> [[Fisher Brothers]] purchased the property occupied by Scandia, as well as nearby land.<ref name=LVRJ-Jul29-2007/> In December 2006, [[Station Casinos]] and Fisher Brothers announced a joint venture to develop a mixed-use project on up to {{convert|52|acre|abbr=on}} of land, including the property of the closed Scandia fun center,<ref name=LVRJ-Jul29-2007/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2006/dec/27/station-reveals-plan-for-mixed-use-project/|title= Station reveals plan for mixed-use project|last= Benston|first= Liz|date= December 27, 2006|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> which was demolished in 2007. As of July 2007, the mixed-use project was to be developed on nearly {{convert|90|acre|abbr=on}} of land, which had been zoned for several thousand high-rise condominium or hotel units, and would have connected to Station's nearby [[Palace Station]] resort.<ref name=LVRJ-Jul29-2007/> Details about the new project's construction and costs were still undetermined at that time.<ref name=LVRJ-Jul29-2007>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/go-west-developer|title= Go west, developer|date= July 29, 2007|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> In 2011, a business named Dig This opened on the vacant property, allowing customers to take control of an [[excavator]] on the dirt lot.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/las-vegas/dig-attraction-will-let-amateurs-become-temporary-excavators|title= Dig This attraction will let amateurs become temporary excavators|last= Illia|first= Tony|date= March 5, 2011|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2011/may/11/get-serious-about-sandbox/|title= Getting serious about the sandbox|last= Corbin|first= April|date= May 11, 2011|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/las-vegas/dig-attraction-fulfills-kids-sandbox-dreams|title= Dig This attraction fulfills kids' sandbox dreams|last= Milliard|first= Trevon|date= May 22, 2011|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/economic-development/dig-plans-expand-orlando-atlanta|title= Dig This plans to expand to Orlando, Atlanta|last= Snel|first= Alan|date= April 30, 2013|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===Paramount Las Vegas=== A casino and hotel and condo resort with more than 1,800 units that was planned by Royal Palms Las Vegas, a subsidiary of Royal Palms Communities.<ref name=Klondike2/><ref name=Klondike/> The project was to replace the [[Klondike Hotel and Casino]] at the south end of the Las Vegas Strip,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://hauteliving.com/2007/09/miamis-backyard/1078/|title= Miami's Backyard: Miami Architects Bet Big on Vegas|last= Wilson|first= Stephanie|date= September 24, 2007|work= [[Haute Living]]|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Klondike2>{{cite web|title=Royal Palms|url=http://dsnet.co.clark.nv.us/dsnetapps/agendaweb/Data/P0190954.htm|publisher=Clark County|accessdate=March 16, 2017}}</ref> beside the [[Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas sign|Las Vegas welcome sign]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rpcholdings.com/planning-entitlement.aspx|title= Coming Soon|publisher= Royal Palms Communities|access-date= March 16, 2017|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140830143737/http://www.rpcholdings.com/planning-entitlement.aspx|archive-date= August 30, 2014}}</ref> The resort was approved in October 2006,<ref name=Klondike2/> but an investor pulled out of the project in August 2007, and the land was put up for sale in May 2008.<ref name=Klondike>{{cite news|last=Knightly|first=Arnold M.|title=Klondike Inn site owner explores sale|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/klondike-inn-site-owner-explores-sale|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 31, 2008}}</ref>
===Pinnacle=== Pinnacle was to include 1,100 condominium units in two 36-story gold glass towers that would be adjoined by three [[sky bridge]]s, which would contain units themselves.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pinnacle Las Vegas|url=http://www.vegastodayandtomorrow.com/pinnacle.htm|website=VegasTodayAndTomorrow.com|accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Mar27/><ref name=Pinnacle-Lawsuit>{{cite news|last=Illia|first=Tony|title=Condo-hotel project faces class action lawsuit|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/condo-hotel-project-faces-class-action-lawsuit/|accessdate=May 10, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 10, 2008}}</ref><ref name=Vantage/> Plans were announced for Pinnacle in March 2005. At that time, the mixed-use project would include two 40-story condominium towers, standing 410 feet, to be built on a {{convert|12|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} property at the southwest corner of West Tropicana Avenue and Cameron Avenue, across from [[The Orleans]] hotel-casino.<ref name=Pinnacle-Orleans/> The land was occupied at that time by the Falconi Honda automobile dealership,<ref name=Falconi/> which closed in October 2004.<ref name=Pinnacle-Lawsuit/> The property had been owned by Angelo Falconi since 1987.<ref name=Falconi/>
The project was being planned by The Falcon Group, an automobile dealership firm; Elysium Enterprises, a local consulting firm; and Praxis Resources Inc., a development company based in [[Pittsburgh]]. Initial plans included retail, office, and restaurant space, and between 592 and 1,184 condominium units, which would range from {{convert|706|sqft|abbr=on}} to {{convert|1235|sqft|abbr=on}}, with prices between $295,000 and $1.2 million. Condominium buyers would be given the option of combining units into a single unit.<ref name=Pinnacle-Orleans>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Condo towers planned near Orleans casino|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/mar/09/condo-towers-planned-near-orleans-casino/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=March 9, 2005|accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref>
The search for a general contractor was underway by November 2005,<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Hubble |title=Condominium craze continues with wave of new projects: Twin-tower Pinnacle, Onyx among projects |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2005/Nov-25-Fri-2005/business/4449330.html |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=November 25, 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060908082940/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Nov-25-Fri-2005/business/4449330.html |archivedate=September 8, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> with Turner Construction ultimately being chosen.<ref name="Pinnacle-Lawsuit"/> In March 2006, Falcon chose Youngblood Wucherer Sparer Architects to design the project, for which the height had been reduced to 36 stories. The project's cost, at that time, was $850 million.<ref name=Mar27>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Vegas Grand condos ready to take a turn toward the sky|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Mar-27-Mon-2006/business/6510801.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 27, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060406154010/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Mar-27-Mon-2006/business/6510801.html|archivedate=April 6, 2006}}</ref> In June 2006, The Falcon Group began negotiations with Berkshire Capital Financial of New York for a $550 million loan, while Pinnacle's sales office was scheduled to open later that month.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Hubble |title=Frame up for Hughes Center tower |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-12-Mon-2006/business/7842885.html |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=June 12, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622101224/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-12-Mon-2006/business/7842885.html |archivedate=June 22, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Berkshire provided $50 million in mezzanine lending.<ref name=Falconi/> Groundbreaking was initially scheduled for fall 2006.<ref name=Pinnacle-Lawsuit/>
The Falconi Honda dealership was demolished in July 2007, to make room for the new project. Up to that time, Falcon Group had spent two years to plan the project and to obtain entitlements and zoning. At the time, the property for Pinnacle was valued at approximately $8 million per acre. By the time of demolition, [[Marnell Corrao Associates]] had been chosen as the new general contractor. Groundbreaking was scheduled for later in 2007, with the opening planned for spring 2010. Approximately 2,000 construction jobs would be created by the project, which would ultimately employee 500 people upon opening. At that time, condominium prices were from the $400,000 range to more than $1.4 million. Amenities were to include a {{convert|3|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} wet deck, a movie theater, a health and fitness center, restaurants, a spa, and an office and business center. Michael Bellon, managing partner for The Falcon Group, said, "We wanted to create something that single-handedly redefined the standard of Las Vegas condominium living."<ref name=Falconi>{{cite news|title=Former auto dealership makes way for high-rises|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/former-auto-dealership-makes-way-for-high-rises/|accessdate=May 10, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 16, 2007}}</ref> Later in summer 2007, Marnell Corrao was replaced by Dick Pacific Construction, which also became a partner in the project.<ref name=Pinnacle-Lawsuit/> In October 2007, after repeated delays, groundbreaking was announced to begin by mid-2008.<ref name=Pinnacle-Lawsuit/>
In January 2008, Green Cable LLC filed a class action lawsuit on behalf of Pinnacle condominium buyers. Green Cable sued the development team for an alleged breach of contract, as construction had yet to begin after three years. The lawsuit stated that buyers initially purchased units with the belief that Pinnacle would be opened by August 2008, and sought at least $5 million in returned deposits, damages and attorney's fees. The lawsuit also alleged that the property site was contaminated with high benzene levels because of dropping ground water levels. Sam Schwartz, a principal for Green Cable, said, "Generally, we believe Pinnacle is an excellent project. At this point in time, however, due to the construction delays the project has endured, the buyers I represent, including myself, believe it is in the best interests of all the parties that we go our separate ways."<ref name=Pinnacle-Lawsuit/> Pinnacle's sales gallery closed on February 22, 2008, and the project's cancellation was announced on March 3, 2008.<ref name=Vantage>{{cite news|title=Financing-plan trouble halts Vantage Lofts work|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/financing-plan-trouble-halts-vantage-lofts-work/|accessdate=May 10, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 3, 2008}}</ref>
===Red Rock project=== {{Further information|Red Rock Casino, Resort & Spa#Condominium towers}} Announced in July 2005, as a joint venture between [[Station Casinos]] and developers [[Stephen Cloobeck]] and [[Irwin Molasky#Personal life|Steven Molasky]]. The project was to be built on the same property as the adjacent Red Rock resort,<ref name=HighRise>{{cite news |last=Benston |first=Liz |title=Station plans residential high rise in Summerlin |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jul/28/station-plans-residential-high-rise-in-summerlin/ |work=Las Vegas Sun |date=July 28, 2005 |accessdate=August 15, 2018}}</ref> and was known under the names "Red Rock Residences" and "The Residences at Red Rock".<ref name=Red-Rock>{{cite web |title=The Residences at Red Rock |url=https://www.emporis.com/complex/115186/the-residences-at-red-rock-las-vegas-nv-usa |website=Emporis |accessdate=August 15, 2018}}</ref> The partnership dissolved in 2006, and the project was ultimately cancelled.<ref name=Red-Rock/><ref>{{cite news|last=Stutz|first=Howard|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Sep-07-Thu-2006/business/9493146.html|title=Station Casinos kills high-rise condo project|date=September 7, 2006|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208101520/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Sep-07-Thu-2006/business/9493146.html|archivedate=February 8, 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
===Rocker Tower=== In 1995, Thomas Greenough relocated his bar and restaurant, Tommy Rocker's, to Dean Martin Drive, west of Interstate 15 and the Las Vegas Strip. In 2004, Greenough began receiving numerous offers from condominium developers for the one-acre lot that Tommy Rocker's occupied. Greenough, who was unable to work out a deal with potential developers that would incorporate Tommy Rocker's into any planned condominiums, later chose to build his own condominium on the property. In January 2006, Greenough received approval for a 46-story, 252-unit condominium tower, to be constructed on his property at a cost of $150 million.<ref name=Rockers-LVRJ/> The structure was to be named Rocker Tower.<ref name=Rocker/>
The tower was expected to be the first in southern Nevada to feature a computerized [[Automated parking system|automated parking structure]], with the intention of saving space and decreasing pollution.<ref name=Rockers-LVRJ/> Greenough had toured [[Vienna|Viennese]] parking garages as part of his research into automated-garage technology.<ref>{{cite news|last=Katsilometes|first=John|title=Cover-up at Tommy Rocker's returns the notorious club to former form|url=https://lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2009/oct/05/coverup-tommy-rockers-returns-club-former-form/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 5, 2009}}</ref> Greenough hoped that the building would be certified by the [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] Green Building Rating System.<ref name=Rockers-LVRJ/> Construction was expected to begin approximately one year later,<ref name=Rockers-LVRJ>{{cite news|last=Packer|first=Adrienne|title=Tommy Rocker joins condo craze: 46-story tower planned for site of sing-along club|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-05-Thu-2006/business/5208193.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 5, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060110041721/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-05-Thu-2006/business/5208193.html|archivedate=January 10, 2006}}</ref> with completion expected in summer 2008.<ref name=Rocker>{{cite web|title=Rocker Tower|url=http://www.4275deanmartindrive.com/|website=4275DeanMartinDrive.com|accessdate=March 16, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060328153830/http://www.4275deanmartindrive.com/|archivedate=March 28, 2006}}</ref> Later in 2006, construction was scheduled to begin in fall 2007, with completion scheduled for January 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rocker Tower|url=http://www.4275deanmartindrive.com/|website=4275DeanMartinDrive.com|accessdate=March 16, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060621161056/http://www.4275deanmartindrive.com/|archivedate=June 21, 2006}}</ref> By January 2007, Greenough had shelved his plans to build the condominium due to increasing labor and material costs in the Las Vegas Valley.<ref>{{cite news|last=Katsilometes|first=John|title=John Katsilometes on what might be the next phase of Tommy Rocker's Cantina (Hint: Think topless)|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2007/jan/18/john-katsilometes-on-what-might-be-the-next-phase-/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 18, 2007}}</ref>
===Sandhurst=== {{main|Sandhurst Las Vegas}} The Sandhurst was announced in October 2004.<ref name=LVS-Oct7-2004>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Another high-rise tower planned for downtown|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/oct/07/another-high-rise-tower-planned-for-downtown/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 7, 2004}}</ref><ref name=LVS-Oct15-2004>{{cite news|last=Negron|first=Sito|title=Plans for new condo high rise are announced|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/oct/15/plans-for-new-condo-high-rise-are-announced/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 15, 2004}}</ref><ref name=LVRJ-Oct15-2004>{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=40-story, 409-unit condo tower going up off Charleston|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Oct-15-Fri-2004/news/25002212.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=October 15, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041029234702/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Oct-15-Fri-2004/news/25002212.html|archivedate=October 29, 2004}}</ref> The project, to be located in downtown Las Vegas, would have included a 35-story tower with 398 units.<ref name=LVRJ-May13-2006>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Sandhurst high-rise still on|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/May-13-Sat-2006/business/7361397.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 13, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719183749/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/May-13-Sat-2006/business/7361397.html|archivedate=July 19, 2011}}</ref> The tower would have had a total of {{convert|900000|sqft|abbr=on}},<ref name=LVS-Jan31-2005>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Developers eyeing other projects for downtown|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jan/31/developers-eyeing-other-projects-for-downtown/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 31, 2005}}</ref> including {{convert|35000|sqft|abbr=on}} of commercial space for shops and restaurants.<ref name=LVRJ-Dec16-2004>{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=City Council approves 35-story condo tower|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-16-Thu-2004/news/25487696.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 16, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041228175931/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-16-Thu-2004/news/25487696.html|archivedate=December 28, 2004}}</ref> Two additional towers and commercial space for the project were also planned for nearby land.<ref name=LVRJ-Oct15-2004/><ref name=LVRJ-Dec16-2004/> Groundbreaking was initially planned to begin in March 2005,<ref name=LVS-Oct7-2004/> with completion expected by September 2006.<ref name=LVRJ-Oct15-2004/> However, construction was delayed several times because of rising construction costs.<ref name=LVS-May1-2006>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=Many stalled in race to the sky|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2006/may/01/many-stalled-in-race-to-the-sky/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=May 1, 2006}}</ref><ref name=Cancelled>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Downtown condominium Sandhurst shutting down|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Jan-13-Sat-2007/business/11956754.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 13, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704134940/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Jan-13-Sat-2007/business/11956754.html|archivedate=July 4, 2008}}</ref> The project was ultimately cancelled in 2007,<ref name=Cancelled/> and the [[Grand Central Hotel (Las Vegas)|Grand Central Hotel]] was announced for the property a year later.<ref name=LVRJ-Apr24-2008>{{cite news|last=Spillman|first=Benjamin|title=Grand plans for big hotel|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/grand-plans-big-hotel|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 24, 2008}}</ref>
===The Harmon Residences=== {{Main article|The Harmon}} The Harmon hotel, located within MGM's CityCenter complex, initially was to include 207 condominiums. Construction on the building stopped in 2008, after structural defects were discovered. MGM later had the building demolished in 2015.
===The Summit / Ivana Las Vegas=== {{Main article|Ivana Las Vegas}} Originally announced as The Summit in August 2004,<ref name="LVRJaug"/> and renamed as Ivana Las Vegas in 2005, when [[Ivana Trump]] became involved in the project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jul-13-Wed-2005/business/2487866.html|title=The Donald's ex-wife plans Ivana Las Vegas condominiums|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|date=July 13, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060104203932/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jul-13-Wed-2005/business/2487866.html|archive-date=January 4, 2006}}</ref><ref name=LVRJ-Jun1-2005/> Ivana Las Vegas would have consisted of a $500 million, 73-floor tower with 945 condominium units.<ref name=LVRJ-Jun1-2005>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jun-01-Wed-2005/news/26640414.html|title=Ivana planning to trump The Donald |last=Clarke|first=Norm|date=June 1, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050603021601/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jun-01-Wed-2005/news/26640414.html|archive-date=June 3, 2005}}</ref><ref name=aug15>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-15-Mon-2005/business/2867912.html|title=High-Rise Development: Ivana buys into project|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|date=August 15, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051029050640/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-15-Mon-2005/business/2867912.html|archive-date=October 29, 2005}}</ref> The tower was to begin construction in summer 2006,<ref name=aug15/> at the north end of the Las Vegas Strip, on {{convert|2.17|acre|abbr=on}} of land that was occupied by the closed [[Holy Cow Casino and Brewery]] at the time.<ref name=LVRJaug/><ref name=LVSaug>{{cite web|url=http://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/aug/20/another-big-residential-tower-proposed-for-lv/|title=Another big residential tower proposed for LV|last1=Shubinski|first1=Jennifer|last2=Negron|first2=Sito|date=August 20, 2004|work=Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasadvisor.com/qod.cfm?qid=3260|title=Question of the Day May 9, 2014|last=Curtis|first=Anthony|date=May 9, 2014|work=Las Vegas Advisor|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> Ivana Las Vegas had been scheduled for completion in December 2008,<ref name=aug15/> but was cancelled in December 2005, due to rising construction costs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-15-Thu-2005/business/4795197.html|title=Ivana Las Vegas luxury condo tower listed for sale|last=Smith|first=Hubble|date=December 15, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051217110712/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-15-Thu-2005/business/4795197.html|archive-date=December 17, 2005}}</ref><ref name=dec16>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-16-Fri-2005/business/4821848.html|title=Development: Now you see them ...|last=Smith|first=Hubble|date=December 16, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051230212036/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-16-Fri-2005/business/4821848.html|archive-date=December 30, 2005}}</ref>
===Vegas Grand=== {{Main|Las Vegas Grand}} Vegas Grand was announced by developer Del American in 2003,<ref name=AmlandOne/> and initially was to consist of 440 apartments and 440 condominiums. The apartment aspect was removed later that year because of rising construction costs, with all 880 units to be used as condominiums.<ref name="LVRJ-Aug6-2004"/> Construction began east of the Las Vegas Strip in March 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Del American|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/9431354/reno_gazettejournal/|accessdate=March 15, 2017|work=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|date=March 27, 2006}}</ref> Vegas Grand was co-financed by Lehman Brothers,<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Condo funding OK'd: Loan approved for Vegas Grand project|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jul-24-Sat-2004/business/24383980.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 24, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041222030944/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jul-24-Sat-2004/business/24383980.html|archivedate=December 22, 2004}}</ref> which took over the project in 2007, after Del American defaulted on its loan.<ref name=Default>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Brian K.|title=Ex-Condo Tower Site Trades for $19M|url=http://siegelcompanies.com/newsroom/ex-condo-tower-site-trades-19m/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|publisher=Siegel Companies|date=July 7, 2008}}</ref> The project was ultimately completed as an apartment complex known as Las Vegas Grand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Las Vegas Grand official website|url=http://www.lasvegasgrandapartments.com/|accessdate=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===W Las Vegas=== {{Main article|W Las Vegas}} W Las Vegas was announced as a condo hotel in 2005. The project was expanded in 2006, after the purchase of adjacent land that was to be used for [[#Las Ramblas|Las Ramblas]]. W Las Vegas was cancelled in 2007, before beginning construction.
==See also== * [[List of Las Vegas casinos that never opened]] * [[List of Las Vegas Strip hotels]]

{{Infobox artist | image =L'eau Qui Dort - Michael Pinsky.jpg | name = Michael Pinsky | image_size = | caption = ''L'eau Qui Dort'' by Michael Pinsky | birth_name = Michael Pinsky | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1967}} | birth_place = [[Leadburn]], Scotland | nationality = UK | known_for = [[Contemporary art]] | education = [[Royal College of Art, London]] |website = http://www.michaelpinsky.com/}}
'''Michael Pinsky''' (born in 1967) is a visual artist who uses diverse media such as video, performance, mapping systems and sculpture to explore geopolitical aspects of a site. Through the displacement and conflation of existing objects and activities he critiques the impact of society’s behaviour. He is known particularly for his projects in the public realm.
== Education== Michael Pinsky studied in England at [[Manchester Polytechnic]], the [[University of Brighton]] and at the [[Royal College of Art]] in London. He was awarded a Doctorate from the [[University of East London]] in 2000.
==Exhibitions & Projects == Pinsky's work has been shown at: [[Somerset House]], London<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.somersethouse.org.uk/whats-on/michael-pinsky-pollution-pods|title=Michael Pinsky: Pollution Pods|date=2018-03-23|work=Somerset House|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en}}</ref> , the [http://www.chengdumoca.org/en/index.html Museum of Contemporary Art, Chengdu];<ref>{{Cite web|title = Foreword_Chengdu MOCA|url = http://www.chengdumoca.org/en/exhibition/column/3361/01/1332|website = www.chengdumoca.org|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref> [[TATE Britain]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://results.ref.ac.uk/Submissions/Output/3253535?searchId=3659680&searchPageNumber=1|title=Results & submissions : REF 2014 : Output details|work=ref.ac.uk}}</ref> [[Saatchi Gallery]];<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://vimeo.com/channels/96791|title=Saatchi Gallery|work=vimeo.com}}</ref> [[Victoria and Albert Museum]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demotix.com/photo/6151830/chinese-pattern-puzzles-created-michael-pinsky-victoria-albert|title=Chinese pattern puzzles created by Michael Pinsky at Victoria & Albert|work=Demotix}}</ref> [[Parc de la Villette]], Paris;<ref>{{Cite web|title = Michael Pinsky - L'eau qui dort - La Villette|url = http://lavillette.com/evenement/michael-pinsky-exposition-cop21/|website = La Villette|access-date = 2016-02-23|language = fr-FR}}</ref>[[Institute of Contemporary Arts|Institute of Contemporary Art]];<ref name="artfacts.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.artfacts.net/en/artist/michael-pinsky-21319/profile.html%7ctitle=ArtFacts.net%7cwork=ArtFacts.net|title=ArtFacts.net|work=ArtFacts.net}}</ref> [[BALTIC]], Gateshead;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://balticplus.uk/panacea-casebook-live-performance-michael-pinsky,-zoe-walker-neil-bromwich-c14775/|title=Baltic Plus - Panacea Casebook: Live Performance: Michael Pinsky, Zoe Walker & Neil Bromwich|work=balticplus.uk}}</ref> [[Centre for Contemporary Art, Glasgow]];<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://cca-glasgow.com/page=236B7D10-868E-4F86-A306909B378E5655&eventid=17616045-B456-1290-932B13E1328151E1pan|title = Panacea - Centre for Contemporary Art, Glasgow|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}{{dead link|date=March 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> [[Modern Art Oxford]],<ref name="artfacts.net"/> [[Milton Keynes Gallery]],<ref name="artfacts.net"/> [[Cornerhouse, Manchester]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://homemcr.org/exhibition/panaceahothouse/|title=PANACEAHOTHOUSE|work=HOME}}</ref> [[Liverpool Biennial]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biennial.com/2014/exhibition/artists/michael-pinsky|title=Liverpool Biennial – The UK Biennial of Contemporary Art - 2016 - Artists|work=biennial.com}}</ref> [[Centre de Création Contemporaine, Tours]];<ref name="artfacts.net"/> [[Armory Center of the Arts, Los Angeles]]<ref name="artfacts.net"/> and the [[Rotterdam International Architectural Biennial]].
Pinsky’s projects in the public realm have often courted controversy in the press. Notable projects include;
''[https://www.somersethouse.org.uk/whats-on/michael-pinsky-pollution-pods Pollution Pods]'' The artist created a series of interlinked geodesic domes which contained polluted air from cities around the world<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/22/world/europe/uk-pollution-pods.html|title=How’s the Air in London? ‘We Should Be Worried’|last=Yeginsu|first=Ceylan|date=2018-04-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>. There was some confusion and concern about whether the environments within the domes could have a detrimental impact on visitors' health<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.architectureanddesign.com.au/news/international-snapshot-building-that-cleans-the-ai|title=INTERNATIONAL SNAPSHOT: Building that cleans the air; Detecting plant feelings; Controversial "pollution pods" {{!}} Architecture And Design|website=Architecture And Design|language=en|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref>. During an interview for BBC1, the presenter David Sillito was '''speechless''<nowiki/>' when the artist explained that he could not use genuine London air within the London pod<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/entertainment-arts-43820243/art-installation-creates-smelling-pods-of-major-cities-air|title=Could you smell which city you are in?|website=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-06}}</ref>.
[https://www.hull2017.co.uk/whatson/events/the-city-speaks/ ''City Speaks'']. The artist constructed a lectern which captured peoples voices and relayed what they said as enormous dot-matrix text ascending Hull's tidal barrier. Many media outlets claimed that the installation was being used for profanities, including a number of sexual references such as "''send nudes''" and "''ejaculation''". <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/08/15/rude-words-appear-giant-art-project-hull-computer-doesnt-recognise/|title=Rude words appear on giant art project in Hull because computer doesn't recognise Yorkshire accents|last=Reporters|first=Telegraph|date=2017-08-15|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/city-cultures-tidal-art-project-10987603|title=City of Culture's tidal art project flooded with 'blue' messages|last=Thornton|first=Lucy|date=2017-08-14|work=mirror|access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/exhibitions/uk-art-project-city-speaks-1052735|title='Send Nudes': A UK Art Project Is Accidentally Projecting Naughty Phrases Across a Town Square|date=2017-08-16|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-US}}</ref> However, it was well received by many, the comedian [[Mark Steel]], said that 'City Speaks' was "''one of my favourite works of art ever''". <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09k6pn3|title=Hull, Series 8, Mark Steel's in Town - BBC Radio 4|website=BBC|access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref>
[http://www.artsadmin.co.uk/projects/plunge ''Plunge'']. The artist marked the predicted sea level in the year 3012 on major monuments throughout London.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Blue rings on London landmarks suggest 3012 sea levels|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16999036|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The eco artists turning trash into treasure - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2012/03/16/world/environmental-green-art/index.html|website = CNN|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref> [[Giles Fraser]], Canon Chancellor of St Paul's Cathedral stated that "''this clever installation imagines a world where St Paul's Cathedral, the Donmar Warehouse and the Athenaeum are all under water, powerfully makes the climate change point''".<ref>{{Cite news|title = In praise of ... Plunge|url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/mar/01/in-praise-of-plunge?newsfeed=true|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2012-02-29|access-date = 2016-02-23|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB|last = Editorial}}</ref> [[Charles Saatchi]] was a little less enthusiastic in the Evening Standard "''Pinsky's artwork may appear a little bleak and pessimistic to some viewers but particularly so to committed Global Warming deniers such as me''"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/story/382911/The-mysteries-of-the-deep-grow-deeper|title=The mysteries of the deep grow deeper|date=2014-02-28|work=Gulf-Times|access-date=2018-05-06|language=ar}}</ref>.
[http://lavillette.com/evenement/michael-pinsky-exposition-cop21/ ''L'eau Qui Dort'']. The artist dredged discarded objects from the depths of the Parisian canals and erected them on the surface of the water. This ecological project was commissioned for [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP21]], but the public interpretation of the work changed after the [[November 2015 Paris attacks|terrorist strike]] on Paris. Elian Peltier from the [[The New York Times|New York Times]] suggested that "''the charged atmosphere after the attacks added tension to the installations''".<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/10/arts/international/in-paris-art-confronts-2-crises.html|title = New York Times - In Paris, Art Confronts 2 Crises|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
[http://www.michaelpinsky.com/project/come-hell-or-high-water/ ''Come Hell or High Water'']. The artist semi-submerged a fleet of cars in the Tyne for the [https://ifacca.org/en/what-we-do/networking/world-summits/third-world-summit/ World Summit of Arts and Culture].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/tyne/5122964.stm|title=BBC NEWS - UK - England - Tyne - Cars are turned into floating art|work=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
[http://www.michaelpinsky.com/project/lost-o/ ''Lost 0'']. The artist used reclaimed street signs to build a monument to the lost ring road in Ashford. The [[Daily Mail]] claimed that the sculpture "''caused a dozen accidents in a month''".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Artworks drive motorists round the bend|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-463780/Artworks-drive-motorists-round-bend.html|website = Mail Online|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Road sign art 'confusing drivers'|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/6285594.stm|newspaper = BBC|date = 2007-07-09|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/media/.../Gfta_awards_offered_Jan_2104.xlsx|title = Arts Council England - GFA award 2014|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
''[https://www.nexus.org.uk/art-transport/commissions/pontis-michael-pinsky Pontis]''. The artist created bilingual Latin and English signs in [[Wallsend Metro station|Wallsend Metro Station]]. This project was shortlisted for the [[Museum of the Year|Gulbenkian Prize]] for Museums.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.michaelpinsky.com/press/pontis/tyne-titian.jpg|title = The Independent - Tyne takes on Titian|last = |first = |date = |work = |access-date = |via = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Latin lessons for Tyneside travellers|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2847385.stm|newspaper = BBC|date = 2003-03-13|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref>
==Awards ==
Pinsky has received awards from the [[Royal Society of Arts|RSA]], [[Arts Council England]],<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/media/.../Gfta_awards_offered_Jan_2104.xlsx|title = Arts Council England - GFA awards 2014|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> [[British Council]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcouncil.cn/en/programmes/arts/michael-pinsky-survey|title=Michael Pinsky Exhibition in Chengdu - British Council|work=britishcouncil.cn}}</ref> [[Arts and Business]], the [[Wellcome Trust]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/About-us/Publications/Reports/Public-engagement/Sciart-evaluation-report/WTX057052.htm|title=Panacea|work=wellcome.ac.uk}}</ref> and his exhibition ''Pontis'' was shortlisted for the prestigious Gulbenkian Museums Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegulbenkianprize.org.uk/press/pr160104.htm#top|title=The Gulbenkian Prize for museums and galleries - Press release|work=thegulbenkianprize.org.uk}}</ref>
